TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill provides for a payment to be made to domestic oil companies as reimbursement for liftings made under the crude oil allocation scheme in February 1986 at the January import parity price (IPP).

As honourable senators will be only too well aware, since late January there has been a dramatic fall in world oil prices. The IPP for Bass Strait crude lifted in February was $43.71 a barrel-as from 1 March the price fell to $27.09 a barrel, a fall of 38 per cent, and it fell a further $6.10 a barrel on 1 April.

Domestic oil companies who, in compliance with the voluntary crude oil allocation scheme, continued to lift high priced domestic crude during February, faced significant losses when this crude was refined and came onto the market after the lower crude oil prices were reflected in lower maximum wholesale prices by the Prices Surveillance Authority. The potential loss to companies for all their inventory holdings at the end of February was estimated to be between $575m and $600m.

Stock gains and losses are a normal feature of commercial activity and it is usually open to enterprises to arrange their affairs so that the financial impact of price variations is optimised to the benefit of the enterprise. In the case of oil refiners, faced with the dramatic fall in world crude oil prices, one option would have been to stop lifting indigenous crude oil until its price reflected the international market. Such action would have been disastrous for the domestic producers, as well as for Government revenues. Consequently, to ensure the indigenous crude oil lifting program was adhered to in February, the Government gave an undertaking to the refiners that it would deal sympathetically with their inventory problem. The Government undertook to reimburse the refiners for their liftings of high priced indigenous crude oil in February. The total gross amount involved is $210.6m. This is calculated as total allocation liftings in February times the difference between the prevailing IPP and the IPP at 1 March 1986. This amount is offset by the value of product sales, recorded as entered for home consumption, made in the period in March before the Prices Surveillance Authority determined new maximum wholesale prices.

The value of these sales, adjusted to take into account both the imported component of those product sales (25 per cent) and those products that do not carry an excise component and are therefore not recorded as entries for home consumption (10 per cent) was $85.8m, leaving a reimbursement to be made to oil companies of $124.8m. The payment will be disbursed to individual companies on the basis of their share of liftings under the crude oil allocation scheme and on the condition that they have settled all inter-company obligations under the scheme.

Clearly it would be wrong for anyone to see the payment as a windfall gain for the industry-it is reimbursement for losses incurred during February, as a result of the 1 March IPP change, over which the refiners had little or no control. They could not take normal commercial action to minimise these losses and at the same time comply with their obligations under the crude oil allocation scheme.

Refiners always bear some commercial risks in holding stocks-and have accepted the normal ups and downs. However, the circumstances they faced in February could certainly not be seen as normal and the payment should not be regarded as setting a precedent. Indeed no similar payment has been made in regard to the 1 April adjustment to the import parity price recently announced.

Following the Government's announcement on 24 February to partially reimburse refiners for inventory losses, there has been some suggestion that similar treatment be given to retailers for stock losses they may have suffered.
However, such suggestions have obviously taken little or no consideration of the different circumstances in which retailers and refiners operate:

retailers were not obligated, like refiners, to purchase high priced stocks in February. Retailers were free to run down their stocks in anticipation of the fall in price of petroleum products. In fact retailers were free to exercise the full range of commercial options to maximise their financial returns and minimise their losses;

while refiners normally hold between 50 to 60 days stock, city retailers hold only three to seven days stocks and country retailers about nine to ten days stocks. The retailers potential exposure to stock losses is therefore a great deal less than for refiners;

retailers are also free to set their prices on the basis of market forces-they have had the commercial option of not lowering their prices until higher priced stocks were exhausted. For refiners the timing of any price change and the maximum wholesale price for their product are set by the Prices Surveillance Authority.
It was for these reasons that the Government could find no justification for extending the stock reimbursement scheme to cover petroleum retailers.

The Bill provides fair reimbursement to domestic refiners who continued to meet their obligations by lifting higher priced crude oil in February under the crude oil allocation scheme. The allocation scheme has operated effectively since the late 1960s and the Government has not been prepared to see it placed in jeopardy because of the totally unpredictable international oil market conditions that prevailed in February. The crude oil allocation scheme provides an assured market for locally produced crudes and an important incentive to continuing petroleum exploration and development in Australia.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER HERITAGE (INTERIM PROTECTION) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The effect of this Bill will be to make permanent an interim scheme to protect the heritage of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders. This will be achieved by repealing the `sunset clause', section 33 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Act 1984. The amendment reflects the Government's wish to retain reserve powers in the protection of Aboriginal and Islander heritage. In June 1984, when the Interim Act was introduced, I indicated that Aboriginals and Islanders had demanded of the Commonwealth a role, backed by legislation, in preserving and protecting places, areas and objects, including skeletal material, which were of particular significance to them and were under threat of injury or desecration.

The Act does not interfere with the existing responsibilities of the State and Territory Governments. Those Governments have legislation which requires them to identify, record, research, interpret and manage Aboriginal sites. Management of sites in some cases may be undertaken by members of the Aboriginal community, though unfortunately this remains an exception. Recording the location of Aboriginal sites is simply one step towards later possible decisions as to which sites are to be protected. The basis for these decisions in the States and Territories have normally centred on issues relevant to University research on Aboriginal matters. On other occasions such decisions appear to have been based on the aesthetic and educative value of the sites. This is especially true of rock art sites. While such values may be important to the wider Australian community, Aboriginals and Islanders want a commitment that areas and objects which are particularly significant to them now, would be preserved and protected.

Although it is certainly true that much of Aboriginal culture has been lost, it is the aim of this Government to restore, wherever possible, that cultural identity and gain community respect for Aboriginal and Islander people and their traditions. Where an Aboriginal community closely identifies with an area which has historical, cultural or spiritual significance, the Commonwealth Act provides a means of protecting that area from actions which may destroy, injure or desecrate it. The Act cannot and will not be used where a State or Territory Government has given assurances, or taken action, to protect such an area. Experience over the past two years has shown that, in most instances, these Governments have been willing to take appropriate action. The Act can and will be used where these Governments are not prepared to use their powers to protect significant areas. Governments may consider that other public interests are sufficiently important for protection not to be given to Aboriginal areas. The Commonwealth Government also considers such interests when deciding whether a declaration should be made under the Act.

The Act in effect provides a means whereby Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders can use the Commonwealth to review decisions by State and Territory Governments. It gives the Commonwealth, authority to bring affected parties together, to conciliate, to mediate and negotiate in order to remove a threat of injury to a significant Aboriginal area or object. Declarations are only needed where such mediation fails to resolve the problem of a threat. The Act has been used in this way during the past two years. No declarations have been necessary in respect to areas of land.

One declaration in respect of significant Aboriginal objects has been necessary. The Act was used to prevent the sale of certain items by public auction. During the period of the declaration negotiations were entered into with the auctioneer by a key Aboriginal organisation, and the items purchased for safekeeping by the Aboriginal community. This experience has clearly shown that resolution of issues can be achieved given the goodwill of parties. Applications have been genuine. Applicants have also been reasonable. State site authorities have been closely involved in reaching suitable agreements to remove or minimise damage. The value of such reserve Commonwealth power is readily apparent. A number of States have commenced revising their legislation and administration of matters such as how decisions on protection and management are taken. Aboriginal communities are considering with greater care what is to be preserved and why, and are seeking to explain these matters in ways which gain wide respect and support in our community. Two years ago the Opposition foreshadowed that this legislation would lead to thousands of applications, and that the Government would act to inhibit land development and planning. These fears have been shown to be without foundation.

One of the critics of the Interim Legislation, the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association Ltd, in a letter dated 1 April 1986 to the Minister for Resources and Energy, the Honourable Senator Evans, wrote and I quote:

While APEA is opposed to the continuation of national legislation on protection of Aboriginal heritage, it acknowledges that, to date, the Federal Government has administered the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Act in a fair and reasonable manner. . .

The preservation and protection of significant Aboriginal areas and objects is now firmly recognised as a responsibility of many parts of the community and not simply that of Government. This Act must remain to cater for exceptional occasions where mediation and negotiation is needed. It represents a positive instrument in raising our awareness of how important sites, areas and objects are to the integrity of a living and vital Aboriginal culture. I commend this Bill to the Senate.

This Bill proposes to amend a number of Acts to remove or alter provisions which discriminate on the ground of sex or marital status to ensure that those Acts will be consistent with the Sex Discrimination Act. Acts done in direct compliance with legislation which was in force at the time when the Sex Discrimination Act came into operation on 1 August 1984 are the subject of an exemption under section 40 of the Act. This exemption for what would otherwise be unlawful acts of discrimination on the ground of sex, marital status or pregnancy operates for 2 years after the commencement of the Act unless extended by regulations either generally or in relation to specified legislation.

In October 1984 all Commonwealth Departments began a review of Commonwealth legislation to identify provisions which would be inconsistent with the Sex Discrimination Act 1984. As a result of that review a number of provisions have been identified by Departments as involving discrimination on the ground of sex or marital status. The Government believes that wherever possible discriminatory provisions in legislation should be removed rather than preserved by regulation. This Bill is one of a number of measures the Government will be placing before the Parliament to achieve this aim. Where legislation is to be otherwise amended by Bills to be introduced in this Session, amendments to remove inconsistencies with the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 will be included in those Bills. This Bill deals with certain measures which are more appropriately dealt with in omnibus legislation rather than by a series of small and separate amending Bills.

The Bill now before the Senate amends ten Acts to effect a variety of changes. The Re-establishment and Employment Act 1945 contains a number of redundant provisions concerning assistance to servicemen in the years immediately after World War II. Some of these redundant provisions conflict with the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 and it has been decided that the opportunity should be taken in this Bill to repeal all the redundant provisions. The Seamen's Compensation Act 1911 and the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1973 at present provide for the payment of compensation to de facto spouses and other dependants of seamen and of Commonwealth employees. The Bill proposes the amendment of the definition of de facto spouse in those Acts to make them consistent with the definition of `de facto spouse' in the Sex Discrimination Act 1984. The Seamen's Compensation Act 1911 is also to be amended to remove a provision which terminates the payment of compensation to a child of a deceased seaman if the child marries.

Honourable senators will see that the review of Commonwealth legislation by Departments has picked up both obvious and perhaps not so obvious instances of discrimination. Honourable Senators will also see that the Government has extended its review into some legislation which is already exempt from the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 for an indefinite period of time, namely the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1973. Whilst this Act is exempt from the operation of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984, it was considered that this was not a good reason why the Act should not be amended, as far as practicable, to be consistent with the Government's commitment towards eliminating discrimination.

Amongst the discriminatory provisions identified by Departments in reviewing Commonwealth legislation there are a small number which will be preserved by regulation. Regulations to this effect are expected to be made in the near future. These regulations will preserve the operation of some provisions indefinitely, mainly where the other options open to the Government to remove discrimination would have been either to remove an entitlement to a particular benefit, or to make benefits available to a wider group, thereby imposing a considerably greater burden on the taxpayer. Honourable Senators will be aware that legislation such as the Social Security Act 1947 is already exempt from the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 for reasons such as I have just mentioned. The proposed regulations will preserve the operation of similar benefits. Of the other regulations proposed I need mention only one in relation to taxation legislation which arises because the process of reviewing all taxation legislation was delayed by the need to give priority to reform of the taxation system. Regulations under the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 will be made to enable a one-year extension of the exemption for taxation legislation until 1 August 1987. The measures in this Bill do not have any direct financial implications. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Ministers of State Amendment Bill deals with the obligation of raising the amount that is able to be spent for ministerial salaries following the rises that occurred in parliamentarians' salaries. This always seems to be an area that occasions a great deal of concern on the part of parliamentarians. Honourable senators rarely raise the issue of parliamentary salaries for fear that if they do so there will be adverse Press reaction. It is a pity in many ways.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to put on the record something that seems to me to be largely anomalous. I think most honourable senators will agree that whatever government is in power the work that is required to be done by Ministers of the Crown is enormous. The amount of time they must spend on their duties is very large and the time they are able to spend at home engaging in normal activities is very small. Let us compare the salary of a Minister, excluding office allowance, with the salary of a departmental Secretary, Level 1-that is, the Minister's chief adviser-excluding office allowance. A Minister gets $82,561 and a departmental Secretary gets $91,704. A departmental Secretary, Level 2, gets $84,000, which is still above a Minister's salary. So a Minister's principal advisers are all paid more than the Minister. This seems to be an extraordinary situation, given the type of work that is required of Ministers of the Crown and the responsibility that they have to take for the final decisions that are made. However, these facts are rarely entered in any Press reports; we see only the adverse reports that politicians are paid too much.

We then go down the line to the retirement entitlements which would be available to a departmental Secretary and a Minister. These are more difficult to compare, but I have taken two typical cases. If someone enters the Australian Public Service at the age of 20 and retires at the age of 60 with 40 years service and having achieved the level of a departmental head, the entitlement is $42,184. Additionally, such a person would receive a refund of his superannuation contributions. This is much more difficult to assess, but it is likely to be in the vicinity of $30,000 on top of that amount. Alternatively, a person entering the Public Service, again at the age of 20, and at the age of 45 entering political life, becoming a Minister and serving for the typical length of time for which Ministers serve-that is, three years-would end up with $34,207; in other words, a good $10,000 less if he becomes a Minister than if he stays a departmental Secretary in the First Division.

I believe that we should not draw from that comparison the conclusion that the departmental Secretary has a salary comparable to a salary which would be paid in private enterprise for that type of level of responsibility; rather, we should conclude that the Ministers of State are underpaid. We should not be looking at a Bill which simply substitutes $660,000 for $630,000. In fact, we should be looking at a significantly higher figure. That, of course, will not occur. Political parties would be loath to take on such an activity. I believe that very easy media operations whereby people run around with television cameras, poke them at cars and so forth, by and large rarely take into account the level of responsibility and commitment that Ministers of the Crown are required to take and the enormous volume of work that they are required to get through. Added to that, of course, a departmental Secretary would rarely lose his job because of a letter whereas Ministers of the Crown can very easily lose their jobs by putting their signatures to a letter, hundreds of which they sign every day. Of course, honourable senators know of instances in the last few years when we have had discussions over such letters.

I believe it is unfortunate that these things cannot be discussed, in light of the comparison between the duties required of a Minister of State and the duties required in private enterprise. I believe there are direct comparisons, but these things, of course, for political reasons, are not taken on because of the fear of adverse publicity. I think it is about time that we stopped asking the impossible of Ministers of the Crown. If we do, it is about time that we started to pay them commensurately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is commencing the second reading debate on the Community Employment Amendment Bill 1986 and I say at the outset that the Opposition does not oppose the Bill. Nevertheless, I shall not be making the sort of speech that my colleague Senator Archer made in respect of the Ministers of State Amendment Bill 1986 because there are, at least as far as I am concerned, six major shortcomings in the Bill. It is my intention to draw attention to those shortcomings as I see them.

SPEECH.PARA: Those shortcomings are, to summarise them: Firstly, the very high cost for low return in terms of permanent employment; secondly, the limited success this proposal has met in its first three years; thirdly, the way in which it has been used to obtain funds over and above departmental budgets and to circumvent the financial restraints imposed by budgets; fourthly, the way some Government Ministers are using the scheme to finance favourite causes or to finance their mates in favourite causes-I might say that usually they are left wing causes that seem to be favoured; fifthly, the use of the scheme in un- economic projects which simply waste money; and finally, what I think is the most important point of all, the fact that it is clear from the so-called `creation' of 87,000 jobs that employers are prepared to employ young people but are inhibited from doing so by the high cost of award wages. Clearly employers can find the jobs when they have to find only half the award wage. If this Government would do something to deregulate the wages of youth in this country, the result would be that the unemployment level of youth in Australia would fall fairly rapidly to something approaching the level of unemployment of adults.

I now turn to those points in some more detail, the first point being the very high cost of the community employment program. In the first three years this program has cost the taxpayers of this country about a billion dollars for approximately 87,000 short term jobs-a cost of about $11,500 per job. Many of these people returned to unemployment after their expectations had been raised and they then suffered the trauma of facing long term unemployment again. The Government really needs to scrutinise carefully all the projects to ensure that they really are providing value for money. Government agencies and departments should not be using the CEP for other than one-off projects. Government departments should be taking on trainees for permanent employment under the youth traineeship scheme as their priority one, not simply recycling the unemployed. In the Australian Capital Territory over 60 per cent of the CEP projects went to government agencies and departments.

Secondly, as to the limited success of the scheme, I say to the Government earnestly that it is placing far too much reliance on this scheme as some sort of program to reduce unemployment. At best it is only a stop-gap to some long term training programs. Only 46 per cent of the participants were in employment six months after leaving the program and about 61 per cent were in employment some time during that period. Those figures are not satisfactory, but I want to look at the other side of the coin. What about the other young people who were not in any employment during the rest of that period after they had finished this scheme? What about the other 54 per cent who were not in employment six months after leaving the program? Would Government senators please give some consideration earnestly to the trauma that those poor kids-I am going to call them kids, they are kids-face. Having had their expectations raised, they go around and tell all their friends and their family that they have a job, members of their family tell other members that Johnny or Betty has a job at last, that they are thrilled with it and all the rest of it, but six months later they are back on the dole with no possible chance of getting back into employment. The trauma which those kids suffer as a result of that I think is shameful.

The cost per job is $11,500 at a time when it is clear that the duration for individual unemployment is in fact lengthening. In July 1983 the average duration of unemployment to which an unemployed person was exposed was 39.9 weeks. By July 1984, one year later, it was 47.8 weeks; and by July 1985, again another 12 months later, it had increased to almost 52 weeks. So the average duration of unemployment when someone becomes unemployed in this country is almost a year at the moment. The latest Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show that over 95,000 of Australia's unemployed have been out of work for two years or more. Last month, so far as youth unemployment is concerned, the rate for youth unemployment increased from 20.8 per cent to 21.4 per cent. So the position for the young is actually getting worse, despite all the slick advertising about Priority One and the youth traineeship scheme. And, I might say, rural Australia seems to be running a poor second.
I quote from an article in the Warrnambool Standard, my local newspaper, headed `Jobs scheme a fizzer in the bush'. The article was written on 18 April and it says:

Rural Australia appears to be running a poor second to the metropolitan area in benefiting from the new Federal employment initiative, the Australian traineeship scheme. Of the first 132 position in Victoria, 128 are based in Melbourne, the other four are in Yallourn.

Of course, Yallourn is a highly industrialised area. In Victoria we managed to get four jobs down in that area of rural Victoria, and the other 128 jobs were Melbourne-based. This job traineeship scheme in itself needs to be desperately looked at by the Government. The article continues:

Not only has the scheme been slow to arrive in the bush, it has encountered several other setbacks . . . The problems include strong objections from unions and employees and potential problems training young people in country areas.

The third point that I wish to make is the way this scheme has been used to beat the Budget limits imposed on Ministers and departmental heads. In the Australian Capital Territory over 60 per cent of the community employment programs covered government agencies or departments and were clearly being used as a means of circumventing the Budget restraints rather than providing genuine employment opportunities. I give examples: The Department of Territories recently utilised the CEP to hand-water trees in Northbourne Avenue. Honourable senators ought to know that Northbourne Avenue runs into Canberra from the north and continues as Commonwealth Avenue to the new Parliament House building. That street has recently had a magnificent new median strip, a grassed area, replaced at great cost. It was replaced at great cost because a special sprinkler system was put in. However, with the problems of Budget limitations it was realised that, if the sprinkler system was turned on, the grass would grow and that grass would have to be cut. So the sprinkler system was not turned on-the Department of Territories did not want the grass to grow. However, of course, the Department did not want the trees to die. So under the CEP the Department had CEP employees going along hand watering the trees and ignoring the magnificent sprinkler system and the grass that is on the median strip.

That is the sort of thing that is going on, as people endeavour to cope with Budget limitations by going around the Budget limitations. Instead of trying to reduce expenditure in other areas, people are endeavouring to avoid the limitation imposed by the Budget. There are many other examples which appear to have merited employment under the youth traineeship scheme or permanent employment. However, they have been covered by the CEP. I refer to certain landscaping projects which are going on in the Australian Capital Territory: Forestry silviculture, Australian Capital Territory schools ancillary positions, hospital pharmacy assistance, stores services, drug referral staff and motor registry clerical staff.

My fourth point relates to the way Ministers use the scheme to finance their mates or their favourite causes. I mention in particular their favourite left wing causes. Ministers of this Government who are not left wingers ought to have a look at what their left wing colleagues are doing in financing causes around this country that follow their political lines. A clear example in the Australian Capital Territory is the grant of $113,639 to Tilly Devine's wine bar for women. Another example is the CEP grant to Jobless Action to produce `The Housing Book', 25 per cent of the contents of which is devoted to the illegal use of other people's property. That is the sort of funding of left wing causes that is being carried on by certain Ministers.

I note that the Minister for Community Services, Senator Grimes, is the Minister in the chamber at the moment. He might be aware of the $17,000 grant to the Tasmanian Wilderness Society for a wilderness shop co-ordinator. I am not sure, but I think that that wilderness shop co-ordinator actually resides in the Australian Capital Territory. The grant is going to the Australian Capital Territory for this person to operate the shop dealing with the Tasmanian wilderness areas. The Nuclear Disarmament Co-ordinating Committee received funding to organise the Palm Sunday marches and also a grant of almost $80,000 for five people to run a peace bus. The Victorian Trades Hall Council got a mere $81,000. The Friends of the Earth received $24,000 plus another $34,000 for a magazine it publishes. The catalogue of these causes seems to go on and on. The money involved is not being used to help long term unemployed people; it is being used simply to promote left wing causes.

The fifth point I make about the scheme relates to uneconomic projects which just simply waste money. The most blatant example is the capital works project in the electorate of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis). I refer to the $2.8m that has been spent so far to provide the people of Footscray with a swimming-pool. That project seems to involve not only funny money but also funny companies. It is a project about which the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, has been strangely silent in the Senate. Why is that project long overdue for completion? What is the total cost overrun? Why were the guidelines bent? These are questions which have been raised in the other place and which have not been answered in any way. As Senator Walsh is the Minister for Finance, perhaps he is the Minister who ought to be answering those questions.

Another project which comes to my mind is the control of weed regeneration in Jervis Bay under the Department of Territories. Ten young people are going around the Jervis Bay area removing by hand the noxious bitou bush. That bush is a matter of grave concern to the coastal areas of Australia. Clearly, a very widespread and extensive program is needed to get rid of it. As I understand it, the bitou bush seeds three times a year. The number of seeds which it drops per square metre is almost unbelievable. It also has some method whereby it is able either to choke out or to poison any other shrub which is trying to compete with it for its territory. The result is that the bitou bush-another import; I think it came from somewhere in Africa-is taking over the coastal areas of Australia. It has certainly taken over along the eastern coast of New South Wales. It ought to be regarded as a matter of major concern and it ought to be dealt with properly.

There is a way to deal with it. A person at Jervis Bay has worked out how to deal with it, and it is by spraying it with a certain percentage of Roundup. But one person with a spray-gun is doing the spraying in the area. The other 10 people are employed going around pulling it out by hand. that is really a hopeless task with such a regenerative plant. The task is described as challenging. In my view it is about as challenging as prisoners trying to break rocks at Alcatraz or somewhere similar. It is also questionable whether either of those two programs provides the sort of work experience that we should be on about. The job certainly needs to be done and done properly. But the community employment program really ought to be about providing long term jobs and not filling in for budgetary problems that departments have in areas such as this.

Finally, I turn to the area which, in my view, is the most important one, that is, the issue of appropriate wages. The private sector is clearly prepared to take on youth and pay them an appropriate wage while they are being trained. There is ample evidence of this. The real problem is the union's insistence on their being paid full adult wages. From the point of view of the youth traineeship scheme, it makes good sense, despite union opposition, for employees to be able to be paid a training wage. But the CEP projects make little sense except as evidence that jobs available.

The real tragedy of all this is that the victims are the unemployed people. They are given false expectations. They are told that the programs will provide them with the necessary work experience to gain full time employment. Instead, at the end of six months, about 60 per cent of them are recycled back into unemployment while government agencies take another dip into the till. Not only government agencies but also private employers have learned that this is way to get some sort of government allowance. They dip into the till in order to have the taxpayers of Australia make up the difference in salary from what they would be prepared to pay in some sort of open market arrangement. We are not suggesting that it be a total open market. But surely it should be possible to fix a minimum wage of $100, $110, $115 or something like that instead of the nearly $200-odd that people have to be paid at present if they are 18 and are given a job.

If the Government and its Ministers responsible for the economy and employment were competent in these matters, it would not have been necessary to renew this program for another three years. It is also an admission that the Government has failed to obtain the co-operation of its masters, the union movement, in getting the youth traineeship scheme under way. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations recognised the difficulties he faced with the unions and sought a modest 5,000 initial traineeships. But, no, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) decided to big-note himself, as he always does, and doubled that number. He attempted to promote the scheme, claiming that there would be 10,000 jobs, and to promote himself, in a massive advertising campaign as though he was promoting a brand of soap.

The unions have sabotaged the scheme from the outset and continue to do so. The Prime Minister, with his special relationship with the unions, should stop posturing and demonstrate that he has the capacity and courage to negotiate with or override the unions to obtain a fair deal for the unemployed youth of this nation. There should be some major initiative by this Government that would bring about some very substantial reduction in the percentage of youth unemployment. It is a national disgrace that, whereas the national unemployment rate is running at about 8 per cent, the youth unemployment rate is over 20 per cent.

The Government really must face up to the fact that something has to be done about it. The job traineeship program is clearly another way of allowing some sort of lower wage rate to be paid to youth. With all due respect, the CEP is another way of allowing a more modest wage to be paid to youth. Why does the Government not face up to the fact and allow youth wages to come back to a much more moderate sum-one that employers would be able to face and to pay without all the enormous commitments that they have, and so bring the youth unemployment percentage in this country back to a more modest figure?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Community Employment Amendment Bill 1986 seeks to extend approval for the community employment program for another three years. It is a simple Bill, the terms of which propose to replace the finishing date of the existing program of 30 June 1986 with the proposed completion date of 30 June 1989. The funding for the program is provided for in each year's Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess the Government is pleased that the Opposition is not opposing the Bill, but judging by Senator Lewis's remarks it did not sound as if it were actually supporting it. He was full of criticism. It is easy for Opposition members to pick out the occasional problem that might occur with the program, the anecdotal evidence of criticism of particular projects and condemn the program because of that. One of Senator Lewis's points that needs to be answered is his assertion that Ministers' favoured causes have been supported all around the country. If Opposition members were honest they would acknowledge that in each State and Territory there are committees which decide on the approval of projects. Ministers do not have the ability to fund favoured causes, even if they want to. Senator Lewis went on to suggest that a preponderance of the projects supported are proposed by left-wing community groups and he listed some organisations which, in his judgment, were left wing. Who knows what some other person's judgment would be about their political leanings? Of course Senator Lewis omitted organisations which have been funded which many of us would describe as right wing. And so they should be funded. We are talking about a community employment program where community organisations, as well as local government and government departments, put up projects for approval. As far as the definition of `community organisation' is concerned, I do not find it as easy as Senator Lewis apparently does to define some of these organisations in the ideological spectrum.

The other matter which Senator Lewis must have been in error about was his assertion that private employers were being funded under this program. It is a community employment program for community groups and public agencies. He must have been thinking about something else when he made that comment. Senator Lewis said that he was appalled and amazed that 60 per cent of projects in the Australian Capital Territory went to government departments and their agencies. I am not surprised at that sort of percentage in the Australian Capital Territory because here one is talking about the equivalent of Commonwealth, State and local government projects in the States. Here they are all done as Australian Capital Territory projects, so I would not be surprised that that sort of a percentage occurred in this community because of its special nature. That sort of assertion cannot be broadened to cover the whole country.

I agree with one aspect of Senator Lewis's comments-the regrettable fact that not all those who are employed under the program end up getting full time permanent employment immediately they finish their temporary work. Certainly, there is a problem of people's expectations being raised and no one would be pleased that people suffer trauma because they find themselves back on the unemployment lists. I would have thought that it was preferable for people who had already had a long period of unemployment to have had some job experience during this period rather than none at all. The logical outcome of Senator Lewis's comments is that there ought not to be this program and that people ought to have even longer periods of continuous unemployment so that they do not experience some employment. There is just no real logic to his comments.

The area that he said was of most concern was the question of youth wages. He acknowledged that, in that part of the Priority One program involving traineeships, there were negotiated lower rates for youth. But he seems to think that the Government ought just to wave its wand and declare that youth wages should be a certain percentage lower than adult wages. What he forgets is that in many industries there are awards which provide for lower wage levels for those who are younger. This is always determined by the system as it exists through conciliation and arbitration. In some industries it applies and in others it does not and it ought to be allowed to be negotiated and arbitrated in that area rather than, as Senator Lewis was apparently suggesting, the Government making some determination about what should occur.

The community employment program has to be acknowledged as being a success. I guess that, if it was not a success, the Opposition would be opposing the Bill. But the Opposition, with its faint praise, is supporting it. It is the largest and the most ambitious labour market initiative ever undertaken by an Australian government. It is a direct intervention into the labour market and it reveals the commitment of this Labor Government to reduce unemployment. We know that the figures overall show successive Labor strategies leading to the creation of not half a million jobs but something like 608,000 new jobs in the first three years of this Government. The other commitment that it reveals is that we want to assist those groups of people most damaged during the seven years of neglect and mismanagement by the Fraser Government. The Opposition does not like the CEP probably because it has been so successful. The Opposition says that it offers only short term jobs. That is the very nature of the program. It is not intended to provide permanent employment and presumably the Opposition would oppose it even more if it were to do that. The objections that the Opposition has to it, for example, the fact that it does not adequately train participants, are not justified and show the Opposition's fundamental lack of understanding of the program.

The CEP was not designed as a program that would solve all the problems of a decade of recession and unemployment. It was designed to assist those who would find the most difficulty in entering the labour market, particularly the full time labour market, in the period of growth which began with the election of this Labor Government. The groups that it can particularly help are Aborigines, migrants with poor English skills, women looking for full time work, disabled people and the young and inexperienced. It is a stepping stone for these groups of people into permanent employment. It was established to take care of the human toll of unemployment which is so often ignored in the talk of broad economics; the human effects of depression; the loss of self-esteem; and the lack of dignity that the community gives to people who are unemployed. The CEP was designed, amongst other things, to restore the dignity and esteem of the most disadvantaged unemployed. It was designed to give them confidence, some experience and some hope to improve their employment prospects. In these objectives the program has been overwhelmingly successful.

Cynical observers have said that the CEP is a ploy merely to reduce the unemployment statistics. The statistics have been reduced by the growth stimulated by this Government and by programs such as the CEP, which has created over 87,000 jobs, but this has not been done as an exercise in itself. Those who say it is merely a ploy obviously have little sympathy for the tragedy of the long term unemployed. Critics, such as those in the Opposition, of such programs as the CEP prefer deregulation policies-when it suits them of course-for example, the deregulation of the labour market and the abolition of minimum wage agreements. Those are the sorts of policies coming from the Liberal and National parties which, no doubt, would inflict great hardships on Australian workers, because they cannot think of any other way to fight unemployment. Senator Lewis continually used terms such as `The Government ought to do something about this; it ought to do something about the other'. This Government, within the economic constraints that apply to it, is doing something, and this community employment program is one of those initiatives.

The proponents of deregulation policies want the market to be the only and ultimate decider of who is employed and who is not, and how much or how little employees are paid. But, as we all know, other people believe that the market exists for the generation of profit, which in turn goes to a wealthy few. This reveals the Opposition's lack of concern for Australian workers and its eagerness to exploit the disadvantage of this country's long term unemployed. The Opposition sees programs such as the CEP, Priority One and affirmative action for women as distortive to the market-although, of course, it does not actually oppose the legislation when it comes forward. In other words, it prefers to sacrifice attempts to establish wage justice and equality of opportunity for the most disadvantaged and replace them with the brutal profit generations of the market. It is not really surprising that the Liberal Party, under Mr Howard, has chosen this road of deregulation and privatisation. It reveals that it is not a party for all Australians; it is there to serve the interests of the wealthy and the privileged.

I turn to some other criticisms mounted by the Opposition against the CEP. As I said earlier, it has raised one-off anecdotal examples and broadened them to generalised criticisms. For instance, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N. A. Brown) in the House of Representatives said that the CEP was set up to serve the political interests of the Australian Labor Party. He supported this by pointing to the fact that some trade unions have been given grants to undertake projects within CEP guidelines. I remind the Opposition that we are talking about existing open guidelines which are administered by committees in the States, involving State and Federal government and community representatives, to ensure that it is administered properly and fairly. Maybe Opposition senators need to be reminded that trade unions are a legitimate part of, and play an important role in, Australian society. They are legal associations fighting to obtain better wages and conditions for their members. If one believed the Opposition one would think that the CEP was funding underground illegal activities.

The Opposition has also criticised the Government for the fact that a grant went to the Nuclear Disarmament Co-ordinating Committee. Senator Lewis mentioned this matter specifically. Of course this Committee organises the Palm Sunday peace marches. This year the Liberal Party availed itself of the work of this Committee by participating in the Palm Sunday marches in order to try to sell its nuclear policies to the electorate. Therefore, in a sense it could be said that the CEP is furthering the political ends of the Liberal Party. The question could be asked: Is the Liberal Party exploiting the peace movement to further its own political interests?

The Opposition condemns all sort of grants to particular organisations that it chooses to criticise. Senator Lewis, in his confusion, raised the matter of a grant to the Wilderness Society which he referred to as the Tasmanian Wilderness Society. I understand that it is now the Wilderness Society. It is a national organisation so it is not surprising that it operates in the Australian Capital Territory. There is no conflict in that at all.

It is amazing that Opposition critics can use such terms as the failed Mr Coleman used in the House of Representatives. He referred to the CEP as being transformed from being predominantly a stepping stone to real work to being a funder of left wing political causes, which is a very peculiar criticism. He concentrated on cultural and creation oriented projects as if there were something wrong with such an area or that it was wrong to spend money on such projects. The CEP is not strictly a training program but it is designed to improve the employability of the most disadvantaged unemployed. Work in such cultural and creative areas develops certain skills amongst participants which are different from construction and maintenance projects that Mr Coleman apparently thought ought to be the sole recipients of CEP grants.

The CEP is providing skills such as administrative and clerical liaison, policy development, policy implementation, communications and public relations. Such skills are generally more transportable than those used in road construction. So if one of the main objectives of the CEP is to improve the employment prospects of the disadvantaged unemployed, one could argue that the more money spent in cultural and creative areas the better the job prospects for participants. The problem is that the Liberal and the National parties just cannot break out of the communists under the bed mentality that they have. If they did, maybe they could grasp the facts and make some constructive suggestions about the operation of the community employment program. I just re-emphasise that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) does not direct the choice of projects. All sorts of community groups, including some of which I would not approve but which are legitimate organisations, have received funding, and so they should have.

I now turn to the success of the program in Tasmania. In Tasmania more than 850 projects have been approved creating well over 3,000 jobs. The Commonwealth has committed $24m to the CEP in Tasmania to aid the plight of the unemployed. The program has worked particularly well in Tasmania. The last figures I have showed that 65.3 per cent of CEP placements went to people who were unemployed for more than nine months. This figure is higher than the national average which was 58.6 per cent. Unfortunately, one of the reasons that this figure is higher than the national average is that long term unemployment is a huge problem in Tasmania because of the sorts of policies implemented by the Gray Liberal Government. One example of its appalling policies is the proposed Tasmania community service program. Under this scheme the State Government will pay unemployed people under the age of 21 the equivalent of the unemployment benefit in return for two days of community service. That is a disgraceful proposal and shows a flagrant disregard for the needs of unemployed youth for training and development skills, quite apart from the question of their availability for referral by the Commonwealth Employment Service for permanent employment.

That State Government program disregards the principle of award wages. It is a cynical move by the Gray Government to reduce the unacceptably high levels of unemployment in Tasmania without addressing either the reasons for that unemployment or the needs of the unemployed. It will reduce the statistics, as suggested by Liberal member Mr Smith in the House of Representatives. He said that technically these people will be no longer unemployed as far as the Commonwealth Government is concerned. He thinks that two days of forced labour is employment, is caring for the unemployed and is providing training. The Gray Government apparently thinks that this is all that is required.

Another indication of how well the CEP is working in Tasmania lies in the fact that 45.9 per cent of placements, excluding jobs on local roads, have gone to women. This is not quite the target of 50 per cent, but again the Tasmanian figure is higher than the national average of 41 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very good.

—I am pleased to hear that Senator Ryan is grateful for that. I refer to some of the examples out of one batch of approvals of Tasmania projects which illustrate the useful work that is funded by community employment program. The Queen Victoria Museum and Art Gallery in Launceston received nearly $20,000 for a project for the conservation of works on paper, which involves training in basic mounting and conservation techniques and clerical and cataloguing techniques-skills that can be used by people in other areas-while at the same time providing much needed conservation of works on paper which were under threat. The Devonport City Council received $12,750 for a project involving the compilation of a photographic land and building register of old buildings and Council owned property; again a worthy project. The Launceston Community FM Group Inc., received $66,000 for people to learn the skills of radio presentation-announcing, interviewing and preparation and presentation of programs.

SPEECH.PARA: The Mersey Valley Festival of Music Inc., received over $14,000 for a trainee administration officer who would learn general office skills such as clerical duties, basic accounting, preparation of funding submissions and planning, organising and co-ordinating the activities associated with the Festival of Music. The Salamanca Theatre Company Ltd in Hobart received $8,500 for a trainee theatre technician to learn about theatrical set, sound and lighting productions, including costing, planning, buying, making and rigging operations. They are just some random selections from one or two batches of approvals which show some of the creative ideas which had led community groups to apply for CEP grants. I emphasise again that it is community groups, local government, State Government and Federal Government initiatives which receive funding. Because of this program many worthy ideas which would not otherwise have come to fruition have done so. If more of the organisations of which I would approve have been funded, that shows that there is more imagination and initiative from such organisations than from those of which the Opposition would approve.

In conclusion I say that when the Labor Government came to power in 1983 three-quarters of a million people were unemployed in this country. They represented the tragic legacy of the Fraser Government. Many of these people had been unemployed for a long time. It is a fact that the probability of gaining employment declines noticeably the longer a person is out of work. The community employment program has attempted to address this problem to break the vicious cycle of long term unemployment. This program is not a cure-all; it was never meant to be. There must be sustained economic growth over a number of years for the unemployment situation to improve. That growth has occurred over the last three years and unemployment has dropped. It is an indication of the success of this scheme that it is being extended. Presumably, if it had failed the Government would have wanted to forget about it. However, it has been successful. I congratulate the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Ralph Willis, on the program. I hope that by 1989 there will not be a need for such a program to be extended once again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the extension of the community employment program. There is a very long list of speakers in this debate, and well there should be, because youth unemployment is the greatest scandal in our community today. Twenty per cent of our young people still are unemployed. The Australian Democrats support the extension of CEP, but we do so reluctantly, because it is a very unsatisfactory band-aid measure. What we would like to be debating today is a fundamental approach to youth unemployment, an approach that would at least give the young unemployed permanent part time work. That is an approach that we could support. It is an approach about which we have talked in the past and about which I will talk again today during my allotted time.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look behind the figures we see that, despite the Government's much vaunted successful economic management leading to growth in the economy and so on, there is not a large growth in the man-hours worked in this country. Certainly, there has not been growth in the sort of jobs on which young people could be employed. We therefore support the extension of CEP simply because we have no other Government initiative that is attacking the very grave and scandalous problem of youth unemployment in this country in a more fundamental way.

The Government is going in the wrong direction with CEP. We are seeing the taxpayers' funds create short term jobs when there is a need to tackle long term unemployment. Unemployed youth need real jobs to give them real prospects in life. We are told that the CEP has given work to 95,000 young people since August 1983. We are told that 95,000 people have had work who would otherwise not have had it. The point is that these people are not getting long term jobs. They are getting work for only a few months. The Government tells us, with some pride presumably, that 41 per cent of people employed under CEP have had work six months after they have finished their time under the scheme. I do not know why we can be proud about that. This means simply that 60 per cent of young people have not had any employment at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is 40 per cent who would not have had work otherwise.

—I will admit that it is a band-aid. That is the only reason we are supporting it. However, it is not tackling the fundamental problem. It is simply recycling the unemployed. It is simply saying to them: `One minute you have a job and the next you are back on the dole'. That is a terrible thing to do to young unemployed people, particularly those who have never been employed. I will not dwell on this point because I think that Senator Lewis covered it quite well. It is the worst possible environment in which to put young people-temporary work for six months then they go back on the dole. Nothing could be designed more to destroy the initiative, incentive and ambition of young people.

SPEECH.PARA: Unemployment has fallen from a rate of 10.4 per cent in 1983 to a little over 8 per cent at present. That is a 2 per cent drop. We still have an unemployment rate of 8 per cent-a very high level. This is in spite of the fact that the economy has been growing at record levels. It has been growing at 3.8 per cent a year-the highest rate in the Western world-yet we have been able to reduce the unemployment rate by only a mere 2 per cent. The figures show that the bulk of the 8 per cent unemployed are young people. Of the 595,000 unemployed, 270,000 are young people. We are still letting the young people of our community carry the can for a very poor economic performance.

Something has to be done. The fundamental thing that we have to do is get investment back into industry. It has been dropping over the last two to three years. There has been no expansion. The expansion of jobs in the work force has been almost entirely in the tertiary sector. This sector has been subject to a revolution in computer technology. Even though expansion is taking place there, job opportunities are not expanding at the rate they should or at the rate which we would expect given the rate of growth of the economy generally. Adding up the total number of hours worked in Australia we find that the figure for June 1985 was only 2 per cent higher than that for June 1983. In other words, there has not been much growth in man-hours worked in our community. This has been due very largely to two factors: It is the tertiary sector that is expanding, and the revolution in technology has not expanded job opportunities at the same rate as we would expect with the growth in the economy generally.

What can we do about it? The short term answer, before we address the fundamental problems of getting the right sort of growth in our economy, is to offer young people permanent part-time work, not six months' work then the dole, but a part-time job, even for one day a week, for as long as they want to work. That could be done straight away if the Government bothered to organise itself and look at the fundamental problems.

I have spoken in this place before about introducing a private member's Bill to tackle youth unemployment and offer permanent part-time work to young people who are unemployed. It is a very simple approach. One would require industry and those employing people generally to make available one work place to be worked on a roster basis, so that instead of one person being employed for 40 or 38 hours a week, four people could be employed for one day a week or eight people for half a day a week. That work station would be rostered. This would not be a great hardship for employers. It could be organised very quickly and easily and would have enormous advantages for the young people concerned. First, it would get them into the work force on a permanent part-time basis. They would be a permanent part of the work force. They would be inside the work force watching how industry operates and how enterprises are organised. Because they would be on the inside on a permanent basis, they would get to know the people in the work force. They would get to know how work is organised and what the requirements are.

This arrangement would exercise discipline on the young people concerned in that they would have to be at work at a certain time at least one day a week. It would allow them to organise their own time schedule around a permanent part time job. It would also allow them to apply for permanent work on the basis that they had been permanently employed, if only on a part-time basis. They could say: `Well, I have been employed with XYZ company; I have had experience, therefore, I am qualified to apply for a permanent job somewhere else.' Alternatively, when a job became available in the place where they were working they would be transferred immediately and could apply straight away.

This arrangement would also have the great advantage that it would give at least some work to young people who would perhaps otherwise be unemployable. Many young people who have been on the dole have dropped their bundle. They do not have any motivation to work. Certainly, they do not have any motivation to work every day for a 38-hour week. As a result their attitude when they apply for jobs is offhanded and casual, and this does not impress employment officers. These young people very quickly become discouraged. They say that society does not want them. They say: `We will just go on the dole and we will stay there forever'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish you would not call it the dole.
—Well, what would the honourable senator like me to call it?
—The unemployment benefit.
—`UBs' for short.

—I will stand corrected. At least if young persons can be assured of a permanent part time job they will have the opportunity to show what they can do. They will have the opportunity to become interested in work and may quickly realise that the idea of working for a living is not so bad after all.

SPEECH.PARA: The company with which I am associated has tried this approach for five or six years and it is working very well. We have a permanent part time workforce of five or six people. One simply has to arrange for a supervisor or a foreman to come into direct contact with a welfare officer associated, for example, with the community youth support scheme who can arrange for young people to try out for a particular job. The social worker and the supervisor of the job discuss directly the best sort of work for the people who are available. They try the people in various jobs and take an interest in them. Both the social worker and the supervisor discuss the people concerned and fit them into the work force on a permanent part time basis. One man can quite easily look after four, six or eight young people, using only one work station.

Senator Lewis took a swipe at the unions, saying that they were not co-operating in this area. I can assure him from my experience with metal workers that they are delighted with this approach to permanent part time work. They have not objected at all and, in fact, encourage it. This scheme could be expanded dramatically, almost overnight, if the Government bothered to get down to it. The private member's Bill which outlines this approach has not been introduced to the Parliament. We are simply not allowed to debate it until it has been drafted in detail, because of some obscure regulation in this place. The Bill is being drafted. It is not an easy Bill to draft, but it will be drafted and introduced as a private member's Bill.

As I said earlier, the problem with the CEP and with the Government's economic strategy generally is that they do not address the two fundamental problems facing Australia today: We are not creating jobs in the manufacturing industry and we are not coming to terms with our foreign debt problems. I am afraid that both the Liberal Party and the Australian Labor Party are taking a similar line in this area. They are both basically saying: `All we have to do is get the economy moving. We do not have to look below the growth in gross domestic product; everything will be right. We have to take a laissez-faire approach. The best way to develop economic prosperity is to let money flow in and out of the country and to let that money be invested wherever people want to invest it'. That is what both the major political parties are advocating. As far as the Australian Democrats are concerned, that policy is not working. It is not the right approach.

Let us look at a couple of figures to show what is in fact happening. In 1983-84 investment in plant and machinery amounted to only $13.75 billion, and in the following year it fell to $13.5 billion. Unless we get money into industry and into developing our manufacturing capacity, we are not going to create more jobs. It is as simple as that. Although we have been expanding the tertiary sector as hard as we can, the actual additional number of man hours of work created has been only 2 per cent over the last four years. We are going to head for bankruptcy unless we solve our balance of payments problem. We will not solve that problem unless we expand our manufacturing sector and start exporting manufactured goods, value added goods.

So we have two fundamental problems-lack of investment in industry and our balance of payments. Both of these problems will not be solved until we have a new approach to the management of the economy. We cannot afford any longer the luxury of following a laissez-faire policy, which says: `Let her rip; let money flow into the country where it will. That will be good for us in the long term.' Record profits have been made over recent years. Is that a good thing or is it not? Cash has flowed into takeovers at an enormous rate over the last couple of months. In 1984 a total of $1.9 billion was involved in successful takeovers. In 1985 this figure had jumped to $4.2 billion. The stock market index jumped 40 per cent between 1984 and 1985. Where is this money going? It is going into unproductive stock market speculation, which is being fed by the takeover racket, which is in turn being funded by the taxpayer. We are squandering our opportunities and we are fobbing off the unemployment problem with mickey mouse schemes such as the CEP.

We must do three fundamental things as far as the management of the economy is concerned if we are to solve the unemployment problem, and the youth unemployment problem in particular. First, we must change the takeover laws to get rid of the present incentive to expand corporations purely through takeovers. Over the last two weeks $2.5m has gone into defending Elders and the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd from takeovers by unwanted raiders. That $2.5m could have gone into a productive capacity and created an enormous number of jobs. The second thing we must do in the management of the economy to create expansion where it is needed and to create employment, which is critical, is to reimpose controls to prevent the large speculative flows of capital into and out of this country. Just recently the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has enabled currency losses to be written off against tax. He is, in effect, encouraging speculation. He is saying: `Well, go ahead and make profits out of currency speculations. We will encourage that to happen by allowing the profits to be written off for tax'.

What do the leaders of industry do? They see the enormous profits that can be made out of currency speculation. They put their efforts behind that and not into expanding their enterprises. The Government is saying: `Good on you, go to it. Speculate in currency. We do not care whether you expand your corporation and its productive capacity in real terms or not'. We have to control the flow of money in and out of the country simply because we have a critical balance of payments problem. We have a grave shortage of foreign currency. We have got to make sure that the money that flows into Australia is being used for productive purposes and not for speculation and protecting companies from unwanted raiders.

The Australian Democrats believe that the third thing we should do to create jobs and ensure the expansion of the economy is to direct money from superannuation funds into productive investment. At present, superannuation funds control 50 per cent of the share market. That is a pretty high figure already, but once superannuation for all is introduced in Australia we will be doubling the amount of money available for investment in this country. What are we going to do? Are we going to sit back and let that money be invested all round the world, or are we going to direct at least a proportion of it into productive capacity in Australia? Unless the Government brings down guidelines for the investment of superannuation funds, it is as plain as could be that the majority of that superannuation money will be invested all round the world and not in productive capacity and in the creation of jobs in Australia.

We heard just recently the Chairman of Elders-IXL complaining on the AM program on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation that if the Government does anything about clamping down on negative gearing for corporations IXL will invest anywhere in the world except in Australia. In other words, the leader of IXL threatened the Government with a strike of capital or a drought of capital in this country unless it was allowed to have a free go and open slather in making money through takeovers and raiding on the stock exchange. The encouragement to invest in stock exchanges and not in productive capacity in the country has to be controlled. The Government has to stop the incentive to use the funds that are available in Australia in speculation rather than in productive capacity.

Until the Government is prepared to face up to the facts of unemployment, look at its root causes and act on them, we will never overcome the problems. The CEP is simply a band-aid measure. We need to create real jobs through controlling the economy, mobilising it on a wartime footing and making sure that the funds we have and the funds we are likely to have in the future are invested in productive capacity in Australia. In the short term, rather than expand the CEP, the Democrats would like to see the Government face up to creating permanent part time work for all young people by requiring by a law of this Parliament that all employers in most categories make one job available to be filled on a roster basis so that we can at least offer all the unemployed young people-every one of them-at least one day's work a week now, not in six months, 12 months or two years' time when the unemployment problem may or may not be solved through the rapid expansion of the economy. The rapid expansion of the economy that we have had-we admit that it has been expanding-has been in areas that are not creating jobs at a sufficient rate to solve the underlying fundamental problems of our 8 per cent unemployment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Community Employment Amendment Bill to extend the operation of the community employment program. Before going on to some specific remarks, I would like to refer to some of the comments made by the previous speakers. Firstly, I would like to make some comments on the remarks made by Senator Coates. The first point I draw to his attention is that, while the community employment program is designed for the benefit of community groups-local government, State government and I think the Commonwealth Government-some community groups are private employers. If Senator Coates cared to cast his eye over the list of community groups in South Australia that have benefited in a real way from the community employment program, he would find that unions, the Red Cross Society and the Marriage Guidance Council of South Australia Inc. and other community groups have benefited. These groups are also private employers.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Coates complained about the negative comments made by Senator Lewis and the Opposition in general. If he stays in the chamber he may hear a few more negative comments. It seems that he wants to turn Parliament into some sort of mutual admiration society. How ludicrous it would be if we failed in our duty to point out the problems of a particular scheme. That is the job of the Opposition and the job of a competent government. If the Government cannot see the problems for itself, the very least it should do is listen to the problems that are raised by Opposition parties, take them on board and do something about them. Senator Coates is surely not asking the Opposition and the Australian Democrats to block all Bills in relation to which, in the detailed operation of the legislation, we would go another way. From what Senator Coates had to say the implication is that he thinks the Opposition should, in some way, be more bipartisan. He is not satisfied that we are supporting the Bill; he seems to expect that all Opposition speakers will simply praise Government activity and not offer any criticism. Criticism is not in his calendar. In his concept of bipartisanship, Parliament would sink into some sort of mutual admiration society and nothing constructive would be done. But given that the implication of Senator Coates's remarks is that we should be more bipartisan, let us turn our mind to the bipartisanship of those on the government benches.

A number of senators and members, including myself, well prior to the debate on this Bill made requests for details of community employment programs in our States. Other senators and members were told exactly the same as I was-that they could not have them. I could have had them had I wanted to pay a few hundred dollars and get them under freedom of information legislation, but my request for information to enable me to participate constructively in the debate was refused. I was told that the reason for the refusal was not that the Government wanted to be recalcitrant or difficult, certainly not that at all. The reason I was given for being refused was that the Government had had so-called experts in to reconfigure the database for information stored in the Department. This reconfiguration apparently means that getting information such as I have had in the past-a simple list of projects, nothing complicated-is now such a difficult exercise that the Government cannot bring itself to make it available to senators or members unless they apply for it under freedom of information provisions and pay the appropriate fee.

I would have thought that a government that was interested in youth unemployment, and a constructive debate in this chamber and in the lower House would have been all too keen to provide that information. Certainly a government that believed there were no further scandals in CEP projects would have been happy to issue the list. What would be the problem in issuing a list if there were nothing wrong with any of the projects? Surely this is an attempt by the Government to prevent scrutiny of the administration of CEP by the Opposition and, presumably, by the Democrats.

I was told I could be given, as all senators and members could be given, summary totals by Federal electorate, but I submit that this is simply not good enough. One can hide all manner of sins, all manner of inefficiencies and all manner of patronage in a general summary total listing by Federal electorates. The Government knows that to govern well and for the Opposition to carry out the task of opposition in a satisfactory manner, we need detail. While it may be important and exciting to discuss the broad brushstrokes of policy, it is the detailed effect on the man or woman in the street that we should concern ourselves with. It is the detail that the community service organisations, the local councils and the State governments need to work their way through to get the subsidy if they wish to participate in the CEP scheme. The operation of the program in detail, rather than the broad brushstroke of policy, is what these groups need to concern themselves with. Again it is the detail that an unemployed person needs to work through if he or she wants to get some sort of experience and wants what benefits there are from participation in CEP. Certainly the statistic on a piece of paper is carried by the Public Service, but when the Opposition asks for details so that it can contribute to a constructive debate in this area, it is refused, under the pathetic excuse that the data base has been reconfigured. If the data base has been reconfigured to such an extent that it cannot produce a simple list of projects by State, the consultants who reconfigured the data base ought to be sacked.

Secondly, I want to make a small reference to a comment Senator Siddons made. He, like many other people, would like to see an increase in the availability of permanent part time work. If I understood his comments correctly, he indicated that the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union, with which he had some involvement, was particularly keen on seeing the development of this practice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prepared to see it developed.

—Prepared to see it developed. If the good senator knows of any other unions which are prepared to see it developed, I suggest he draw up a list of those relevant unions and make the list available to the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) who is at the table and who is also the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women.
