The lack of permanent part time work is one of the greatest problems for women seeking to enter or re-enter the work force and the unions are seen as being the most obstructive group to the development of this practice.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the comments I wish to make on my own behalf. The Government has decided that it wants to extend CEP, and I simply wish to draw the Government's attention to certain problems with CEP, in the perhaps naive belief that if it can it will look at them and fix all or some of those problems. Since the spirit of bipartisanship is overflowing in the chamber this morning, if I have been misinformed and the Government is aware that I have been misinformed and that a problem I have presented as a problem in fact is not a problem, I would be delighted to receive the information from the reconfigured data base that will enable me to understand my error.

I acknowledge that in CEP there have been many useful projects but, as I said, there are problems. One problem in particular is that short term job creation exercises are not the complete answer. One particular problem with the project, in my view, is the type of work that is offered. Many people are trained under CEP in skills that are not readily marketable after the program has finished. The second problem I see is the cost efficiency and accountability of the management of the program. In this sense I think there is a complete lack of real accountability of taxpayers' funds in regard to the responsible management of schemes, particularly once the funds have been handed over. A third problem I perceive with the program is the inflexibility of the guidelines. These guidelines have been the subject of complaint by a number of groups which have participated in the scheme. These groups say that this inflexibility will either prevent them or turn them off wanting to participate in the scheme in the future. The fourth particular problem with the scheme is its substantial cost and the enormous investment of over $1 billion over a period of three years for a total of 87,000 short term jobs.

Senator Lewis has already referred to some of the projects as being political activities and he has also made reference to the problem whereby State and local government agencies use CEP to top up their recurrent activities. I will deal first with the problem of the inflexibility of the guidelines. The Government, in my view, would do well to turn its attention to the comments made by various councils which have participated in this scheme. I ask the Government to bear in mind that, at least in South Australia, it is the local councils which take up approximately 50 per cent of CEP funds. The District Council of Hawker in South Australia wrote me a letter in which it indicated that it would no longer be participating in the scheme. The council said that it had done so in the past but that it was most unlikely it would take part in future in further schemes for several reasons. The council said:

Firstly, for a small Council such as ours the Scheme is very tied by rules and regulations and is unworkable for us where we have to retain a climate of great flexibility in our works programme and scheduling.
Secondly, in remote areas such as ours there is great difficulty in finding appropriate persons to carry out infra structure jobs that we are involved in from time to time within our work schedule.
The Clerk of the District Council of Hawker went on to say:

For us, or for any other small Council in South Australia, I guess the great difficulty is to match a relatively inflexible scheme with the need to retain flexibility in our management of human resources and financial resources in a small Local Government climate.

It is not only in my State that the local councils are complaining. I refer to an article in the Age on 11 November 1985 in which the Northcote City Council threatened to withdraw from the Federal Government's community employment programme, claiming that job schemes had been administered in an `insensitive and impractical manner'. A particular councillor is quoted as saying:

`The Federal Government appeared to have an obsessive concern with the expectation that council could effectively employ 45 long-term unemployed people, with a common commencement and termination date for the project, and that terminations, non-attendances and workers' compensation claims would not occur,' he said.

`In reality, council experienced delays in undertaking the necessary work as well as higher-than-average workers' compensation, absenteeism in some cases and wet weather. Also the CES office found it impossible to provide a large number of suitable employees over a short period of time, let alone all on the one day.'

I could go on. There are bundles and bundles of examples of complaints from local councils and from community groups about the difficulty created by the inflexibility of the guidelines. Let me make it clear that I am not suggesting that the Government so loosen up the guidelines that there are no controls at all, but surely the complaints about inflexibility indicate that some attention needs to be paid to providing at least in some ways some flexibility for groups which wish to participate in the scheme.

The next point I make relates to the lack of private sector involvement in the scheme. I understand that it was never intended in the first place that the private sector, as a business group, participate and that the only private employers who would be able to get some benefit from the CEP scheme would be community groups which could be characterised in a secondary way, as private employers. It is my belief that the Government should be looking to creating real jobs for young people, firstly in the private sector, but not exclusively as it should also create some in the public sector. In this program the public sector has a field day. As I have indicated, local government in South Australia gets about 50 per cent of the funding and 50 per cent of the jobs under the community employment program. The State Government gets about 20 per cent of the funding and the jobs. The community groups-the word `community' is used to identify the general nature of the scheme, which is known as the community employment program-get only 30 per cent. Even within the balance of entitled groups, that seems to me to be an imbalance. In my view, more money should be going to community services and less to State and local government.

The cost of those jobs that are created for the short term-I understand that they are not meant to be long term jobs-to give experience to young people is substantial. I understand, looking at the costs involved, that there is a capital element in a large number of the jobs. If the database had not been reconfigured so that we are no longer able to get some detail, I would be able to elaborate on the extent to which the capital element of the CEP played a part. It would seem useful for this chamber to understand what portion of the money allocated to the CEP goes in actual salaries and what portion is attributed to the capital element. Without the detail I am unable to make much comment on that issue.

There are a few things I wish to say. Firstly, the targeting of the program to State and local government, particularly to local government, can have a particular effect in that local government will redirect its budget and its priorities in order to gain the capital benefit from the Commonwealth Government. I believe that that effect on local government should be considered. One needs only to look at some of the projects that have been undertaken by local government to get just some idea of where that money is going. In South Australia the highest number of CEP jobs in the local government sector are in a classification of jobs called kerbing roads and drainage. The second highest number of jobs are in a category referred to as parks and gardens, and the third highest are clerical jobs, and so it goes on. The question that I believe the Government should be asking is: If councils are now undertaking the kerbing roads and drainage jobs so as to get the benefit of some capital portion of money from the Government, when this program ends where will they get the money to go on with the kerbing roads and drainage work so that they can offer the young people the opportunity to use the skills that they have gained under the CEP? The answer is that they will not find funds within their own budgets to extend that work to be able to give all those people kerbing roads and drainage jobs.

The Government should be paying some attention, within the guidelines and the operation of the scheme, to the classification of jobs that are offered to young people to try to find some mechanism of matching the need for work for unemployed people and the need for the jobs to be done, with the opportunities that will exist for young people to apply their skills after the CEP work has finished. If there is not a closer relationship to the sorts of jobs that are available afterwards, the effectiveness of the scheme in giving people skills is diminished.

The second point I make about public sector involvement in this scheme to the exclusion of the private sector is simply this: Going through the projects that are offered-I undertook the task with regard to South Australia for a period running from 1 July 1984 to 21 May 1985, and this was prior to the database being reconfigured, so I was able to get some detail-one finds that the cost of the jobs to the Commonwealth varies substantially. For the benefit of comparison and to put these jobs into some kind of common form, I have worked out the cost to the Commonwealth on a per annum basis, even though a lot of the jobs are for a period of 12 or 48 weeks. Jobs run for a varying number of weeks.

For the period I referred to, the highest cost per person per annum was $29,276. This related to a grant for the Aboriginal Community Affairs Panel. The activity was described as being `an Aboriginal community recreation area'. The classification it came under was sport and recreation. The number of jobs created was six, and they lasted for 14 weeks. I am well aware that those six people were not paid $29,276. As I have already said, a capital element is involved. But I indicate that to give six people a job and to give them some experience-very limited experience because it was only for 14 weeks-the cost to the Commonwealth, worked out on a per annum basis, was $29,276. That does not seem to me to be a cost-efficient way of giving young people skills which will enable them to get a job after the program has finished. The least expensive program on a per person per annum rate cost $5,824.

The Government should be turning its mind in the case of the so-called job creation schemes-schemes to benefit the unemployed-to the role the private sector can play in using the money available in a more cost-efficient way than perhaps local government and State government can. I agree with the comments that Senator Lewis has already made that some State government departments are just using the CEP to get young unemployed people to do all the hack work that the departments cannot be bothered doing themselves. They want to have little lackeys to run around and top up the jobs that they do not want to do. I cite in particular the employment of a female stocktaker at Elizabeth High School. I query what that child has learned from doing a stocktake that someone else could not be bothered to do. Sure that young unemployed person should get the benefit of some community employment program training, but she should not be employed to do stocktaking at Elizabeth High School. I would have thought that a competently run administration could keep up a regular basis with its records and would not need someone to come in and do a major stocktake in that sense. That is all I want to say with respect to the public sector.

There is one further point I wish to make with respect to private sector involvement. I acknowledge that the Government, in planning for the Australian traineeship scheme under the Priority One scheme, has designed that scheme to include private enterprise. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in his statement last year, indicated that small business would take up the majority of these traineeships. He also promised to put in place 10,000 traineeships in the first financial year, which ends on 30 June. We all know that the sad fact is that only 903 of these traineeships are in place at the moment. The even sadder fact is that only 33 of them are private enterprise jobs. That should surely be spelling out to the Government that there are some problems in getting private enterprise involved in the traineeship scheme. The Government should be turning its attention to those problems.

I would have welcomed some comment on and some reference to those problems in the report which was issued this week entitled `Young Australia Part B-Priority One in Progress'. Even if there were not a detailed reference, there should at least have been some commitment and some indication that the Government had some ideas about what was wrong with the traineeship scheme and what it could do to attract private enterprise to participate in it. The traineeship scheme has some real benefits to offer young Australians if only the Government can get it off the ground. It seems to be having some difficulty in doing that at the moment.

I wish to comment on some remarks made by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) in the House of Representatives. He cited as one of the most outstanding achievements of the CEP its success in meeting the objective of equal female representation in jobs created under the program. I heartily endorse women getting their fair share of government funding or of opportunities created by government funding for employment programs or, indeed, for any program. However, I do believe the Government should turn its mind to the detailed application of this principle at the level where people are taking the jobs-down at the Commonwealth Employment Service offices. There have been reports-admittedly not such an influx of them that they are making headline news-of young girls who have gone to CES offices and asked to participate in the schemes that are available. They have taken the jobs on a broad job description, only to find out when they get to the place of employment that the work is too heavy for them and is of such a nature that had they known what was involved in the first place they would not have taken those jobs. I support the concept of women getting an equal share of government money, but I hope that that as a goal does not override the needs of the women who want the jobs. I hope that it does not lead public servants, in their desire to put government policy into practice, to con young girls into taking jobs that they otherwise would not have taken.

A number of comments have been made in this debate to the effect that the Opposition does not understand the role of the CEP because of its constant references to the fact that the program is not providing permanent work. Of course the Opposition does understand that CEP participants are not being offered permanent work, and of course there is no expectation that the recipient of a grant will keep an employee on after that grant has finished, in a way that might have developed under older schemes such as the special youth employment training program. Nonetheless, the fact remains that youth unemployment is at an all time high. This program has been going for some time and it does not appear to have had any substantial effect on reducing the rate of unemployment, certainly in my State. In summary, I simply wish to say that it would be a welcome change if members of the Government, instead of spouting about the lack of bipartisanship on the part of the Opposition, displayed some themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Community Employment Amendment Bill 1986 extends the community employment program. The Government will continue the highly successful CEP for a further three years beyond next month. The Government remains committed to a substantial job creation program aimed at tackling the problems of the long term unemployed and other particularly disadvantaged job seekers. A total of $290m has been allocated to the community employment program in the current financial year, with a forward commitment to the program of $140m next financial year. The rate of CEP approved activity in 1985-86 will be maintained in line with that achieved last year and it is expected that 30,000 new jobs will be approved throughout Australia under the program this financial year. Taking account of the carryover of jobs approved last financial year, it is anticipated that about 45,000 Australians will be assisted this financial year. Despite the general improvement in the labour market over the past two and a half years, long term unemployment still remains a serious problem. The number of Australians unemployed for nine months or more has dropped by 9 per cent over the past two years, but unfortunately there are still 220,000 Australians in this position of long term unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: After listening to remarks made this morning by Opposition speakers and reading carefully those made in the House of Representatives recently on this legislation, it is very clear that the Opposition is divided in its attitude to the community employment program. Some members of the Opposition parties claim that the CEP is `wasteful and inefficient and does not create permanent jobs'. Yet other Liberal Party and National Party MPs are more than happy to gain publicity by announcing CEP projects in their electorates. It seems that coalition members of parliament are prepared to support or oppose the CEP whenever the opportunity suits them. Some Opposition members are quite prepared to have their beaming faces photographed at the opening of CEP projects which directly benefit their electorates. Other Opposition members take the opposite tack and speak against the CEP in the Parliament and the media whenever the opportunity arises.

This inconsistency and division among the Opposition ranks was evidenced by recent statements from the Liberal members for Mayo (Mr Downer) and Barker (Mr Porter) in my home State of South Australia. Their statements on the CEP contrast very sharply, even though they are neighbouring members of parliament from South Australia. While the honourable member for Mayo was decrying the CEP as a waste of public money, his neighbour, the honourable member for Barker, was announcing in the Adelaide News of 24 April CEP grants in his electorate worth almost $135,000. That is one of many announcements that I have discovered by Liberal Party members of parliament who are very keen to jump in and announce the benefits to their electorate provided by this Government when the opportunity suits them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shocking hypocrisy!

—As Senator Cook points out, it is shocking hypocrisy. On this particular occasion Mr Porter announced grants in his electorate provided by the Hawke Labor Government of $135,000 for works by the Millicent Council in south-eastern South Australia and a number of school grants in that region. It would appear that Mr Porter is not too proud to associate himself with the CEP, while his neighbour, Mr Downer in the electorate of Mayo, is very free with his criticism of the program. In fact, Mr Downer said in the House of Representatives on 20 February this year that he had significant reservations about the CEP. He described the scheme as:

SPEECH.PARA: ``. . . an extremely inefficient way to both provide facilities and create jobs.

Mr Downer went on to say that the community employment program was not attacking the causes of unemployment. These statements were made by a Liberal member of Parliament who supported a government which presided over the destruction of hundreds of thousands of jobs in this country. While Mr Downer was making those statements in the House of Representatives, he omitted to say that the Hawke Labor Government-which I presume he would describe as a socialist government-had provided some $7.9m since the inception of the CEP to create 933 jobs in his electorate. Nine hundred and thirty-three employment positions were created in the Mayo electorate, yet that member of Parliament is very sceptical about the community employment program. In his speech he ignored the very substantial benefits to his electorate that have been provided by this Labor Government.

Earlier this morning Senator Vanstone used the word `patronage' to describe the CEP. That word was actually used by Senator Vanstone when she suggested that these grants were allocated between electorates according to political favours. But as I have just pointed out, we provided $7.9m as patronage-to use Senator Vanstone's jargon-in a Liberal held electorate in South Australia. This money created 933 jobs in the electorate of a member who does not support the community employment program.

Another example of the Opposition's division over the community employment program is evidenced by remarks by Senator Jessop in this place on 14 March, which cast aspersions on the operations of a company known as Trojan Owen and Associates Pty Ltd. As I pointed out earlier, one of Senator Jessop's colleagues from South Australia, the honourable member for Barker, Mr Porter, is eager to jump in whenever the occasion presents itself to announce the grants in his electorate which have been provided by the Hawke Labor Government. But Senator Jessop in this chamber attacked the company Trojan Owen, which has been managing a number of CEP projects. Trojan Owen is an established and reputable company. It has a reputable record as a management consultant for job creation programs. In South Australia, Trojan Owen has been involved in 14 successful CEP projects. One of these, the Chelsea cinema redevelopment in Marryatville, which involved my local council, the City of Burnside, won a Civic Trust commendation for design and construction. This company, which has been maligned by Senator Jessop, was involved in a project which won a Civic Trust commendation for design and construction. Of course, Senator Jessop did not refer to that fact in his remarks in this chamber some time ago; he ignored it. It seems that some members of the Opposition will go to great lengths to discredit the community employment program while others want the credit for opening new projects in their electorates. The fact is that Trojan Owen has been involved in a number of projects of great benefit to the South Australian community, and I think that should be placed on the record.

Not only do the Opposition's claims about the CEP lack one ounce of credibility, but also they completely ignore the rationale and the objectives of the program. After all, the CEP is not designed to create permanent jobs; its fundamental purpose is to create short term jobs to provide employment and, most particularly, work experience for the most disadvantaged unemployed members of our community. In fact, without social assistance these unemployed persons have little chance of getting back into employment.

The Opposition parties refuse to see the CEP program in its proper context. It is the overriding aim of general Government economic policy to create permanent jobs. This Government has successfully attacked the causes of unemployment. It has created jobs. When the Government came to office Australia was in the grip of a recession; job opportunities were disappearing, and many Australians faced a bleak future. The Hawke Government's top priority was to stimulate economic recovery and create the jobs necessary to reduce unemployment. Since the National Economic Summit Conference in April 1983-just over three years ago-over 600,000 new jobs have been created. Over a three-year period, 600,000 extra Australians have found work.

TALK.START.PARA: —A promise delivered.

—It is a promise delivered. That figure is almost 100,000-not 1,000-above the Government's original target, and I am pleased to say that it has been achieved with several months to spare. I say for the record, seeing that honourable senators opposite have a fetish about the role of the private sector in job creation, that the great majority of the 600,000-plus new employment positions which have been created in our country in the last three years-in fact, over 86 per cent-have been in the private sector.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the more pleasing achievements in association with Australia's labour market recovery has been the reduction in youth unemployment rates. I heard Senator Vanstone a moment ago trying to tell this chamber that youth unemployment in Australia is at present at record levels. She seems to have forgotten, very conveniently perhaps, the record of Mr Howard when he was Federal Treasurer. But the fact is that when this Government came to office in 1983, following five years of Mr Howard's stewardship of the nation's finances as Federal Treasurer, the youth unemployment rate was in the vicinity of 28 or 29 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —And climbing.

—And climbing, as the honourable senator points out. At present the youth unemployment rate is 21.8 per cent. I cannot see how Senator Vanstone has any basis for making the claim that youth unemployment at present is at a record level. In fact, from 1983 to 1986 the youth unemployment rate has fallen by over 6 percentage points. That is yet another false statement by an Opposition senator in this debate nailed down, and nailed down very firmly.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Government's success in creating new permanent jobs is in stark contrast to the record of the Fraser-Howard Government. The economic policies of that Government, with which Mr Howard was so intimately associated, were responsible for destroying thousands of jobs. In the last year when Mr Howard was Treasurer some 186,000 Australians lost their jobs. The objective of the community employment program is to assist the long term unemployed, Aboriginal members of the community, disabled people and others who have been unable to benefit from the general growth in employment opportunities as a result of general economic policy. In that sense the community employment program supplements the general policies of economic expansion so that the Government can be seen to have a two-pronged policy to reduce unemployment.

This Government has recognised the need to break the unemployment trap-that is, the tendency for unemployed persons to encounter increasing difficulties in finding employment as the duration of their unemployment extends-by providing appropriate work experience. This will also improve the unemployment prospects of the most disadvantaged jobless by restoring their self-confidence, job skills and, most importantly, acceptability to employers.

It is clear that the community employment program is attacking the causes of unemployment, despite the comments of the honourable member for Mayo, Mr Downer, that it is not. I believe that the community employment program has already achieved its specific aims. It has created a large number of jobs at a reasonable cost. It has successfully targeted those disadvantaged unemployed groups most in need of assistance and it has successfully redirected many long term unemployed back into the work force.

From the inception of the community employment program to the present day, some 18,200 projects have been approved at a total cost to the Commonwealth Government of $1,035m. Translating these figures into jobs, some 100,000 Australians have found employment on community employment program projects. The average cost to the Commonwealth Government of a six-month job has been around $10,000. The labour component of the community employment program, set at a target of 65 per cent of the total Commonwealth contribution per pro- ject, has been exceeded, on average by some 10 per cent. Although the primary objective of the community employment program is to create jobs and to provide suitable work experience for the long term unemployed, projects funded under the CEP are also required to provide facilities and services of lasting benefit to the community. I should also point out, in view of some of the criticisms that have been made about the scheme, that funds allocated to the CEP projects have been overwhelmingly spent on creating jobs and have not been soaked up in administrative costs. In fact, administrative costs to the Commonwealth Government, including funds for State and Territory administration, amount to only 3 per cent-I repeat, only 3 per cent-of the total community employment program budget.

I would now like to cite some specific examples of CEP projects which have benefited the community in my State of South Australia. The railway project at Victor Harbor, which is in the Mayo electorate-we have heard something about the honourable member for Mayo this morning-was approved in 1985 and will upgrade the historic and scenic railway between Adelaide and Victor Harbor. This project will be a major boost to South Australia's tourist industry. The initial grant for the project is some $1.2m and 84 persons will be employed, 75 of whom are in the long term unemployed category. Moreover, this group comprises 15 women, three persons of Aboriginal descent and 10 handi- capped Australians. I am pleased to note from reports in the local newspaper, the Victor Harbor Times, that the project is already stimulating the regional economy. A bus service has been started to ferry CEP workers to the site and local shopkeepers are benefiting from the presence of 84 new railway workers in the district. Yet this project in the electorate of Mayo is operating under a government scheme which the local member, Mr Downer, would prefer to be replaced; a project which has created 84 jobs in his electorate. Also in that electorate $140,000 has been allocated to upgrade the causeway and Granite Island at Victor Harbor. Nineteen jobs are involved there.

A range of new community employment program projects have been announced for South Australia this year. I have mentioned a couple which have been announced by the Liberal member for Barker, but I now refer to some others. A CEP grant of $248,000 has been provided to the Port Adelaide City Council for redevelopment of the old Port Adelaide War Memorial Swimming Pool site. Seventeen unemployed members of the community will work for 40 weeks to fill in a disused swimming pool, construct tennis courts on the site, refurbish change rooms, plant grass and landscape the area. The City Council of Mount Gambier will employ 12 people for 24 weeks with a CEP grant of over $132,000 to provide tennis and netball facilities at three of the city's sports parks. The Greek Women's Society of South Australia will receive $106,000 to employ seven persons for 35 weeks to establish a women's centre. At Port Lincoln the Lincoln South Football Club will receive $177,000 to employ over 200 persons for 25 weeks to extend the club's facilities. Since the inception of the community employment program a total of over 8,800 jobs have been approved in my State of South Australia at a cost to the Commonwealth Government of some $88m. The average prior unemployment duration for all CEP participants is over 12 months and the long term unemployed have represented 61 per cent of all placements since the beginning of the program.

In contrast to the knocking by some members of the Opposition, evaluations of post-CEP employment show clearly that former CEP participants have had considerable later success in finding work. A survey of former community employment program participants carried out in July last year found that some 60 per cent had been employed in the six months subsequent to their leaving the community employment program. So that is a quite respectable figure-some 60 per cent of former participants have had some further work after leaving the program.

Short term job creation programs such as the community employment program of course have positive psychological effects on the long term unemployed, as I believe would be expected by any reasonable critic of the program. In fact, recent research undertaken by Dr Anthony Winefield of the University of Adelaide clearly shows that programs such as the community employment program help to restore the dignity, self-esteem and confidence of the long term unemployed in our community. These psychological effects are clearly apparent and measurable and continue beyond the program even when the participants do not proceed to other forms of employment. That is a very important aspect of this program which has been largely overlooked by Opposition speakers.

The CEP is the largest and most ambitious short term job creation initiative ever undertaken by an Australian government and it has been an outstanding success. The program evaluation results show that the CEP has achieved its objective of creating short term employment. It has provided essential work experience for those unemployed groups which have been unable to benefit from the general uplift in the Australian economy. Although this point may not mean much to the members of the Opposition, a CEP job is an offer of hope and opportunity for those unfortunate Australians in a position of unemployment. I commend the Government for extending the community employment program beyond this financial year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In December 1985 the Government announced its intention to continue the community employment program, widely known as CEP. Today we find ourselves in a very different situation from when the first CEP Bill was introduced in August 1983. The economic landscape of 1983 saw a much higher level of unemployment. Since that time the community employment program has been only a small part of the Hawke Labor Government's rebuilding of the economy; a rebuilding of employment and employment opportunities that was scoffed at by the Opposition when it was proposed in 1983. Now that the runs are on the board and the economy which had a negative growth rate in 1982-83 has seen record growth rates, we are in a much different position.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Government stated its intention was to create 500,000 jobs in the first three years of office, the Opposition reacted with two responses. The first response was derision. As the members of the then Opposition have so clearly demonstrated in the Howard-Fraser years, such a vision was beyond their grasp. They proved very much better at abolishing jobs than creating them. The second response was to say that all such jobs created would be in the Public Service or job creation schemes. The truth of the matter is, of course, that that proved not to be so. The number of jobs permanently created by the turnaround in the economy that this Government engineered proved to be in the private sector. The increase in employment went hand in hand with increased consumer confidence.

The community employment program was a response to the problem of long term unemployment which existed when we came to government. The parlous state of the economy in 1983 meant that something had to be done. In November 1983 over 260,000 Australians, or 41.8 per cent of all those out of work, had been unemployed for nine months or more. This tragic waste of human resources was such that the Hawke Labor Government wanted to bring in a scheme which would address both this problem and the problem that for years the disadvantaged job seekers had experienced poor employment prospects. Since the inception of the CEP many community projects have been successfully completed. The success of this scheme was not only that it in part reversed the long term problems of unemployment, or that it gave disadvantaged job seekers a share of the benefits of the economic recovery, but also that it led to the building of numerous community assets. These assets are across the country and are far too numerous to mention here.

The scope of CEP is enormous-enormous in both financial and human terms. Since its inception some 98,391 jobs have been created. The total funds that have been allocated so far are over a billion dollars. In South Australia some 8,678 jobs have been created in this scheme at a cost to the Government of $86.55m. In my home State of South Australia many small projects as well as many large ones have been completed or are in the process of completion. It is hard to think of an area that has not been affected by this scheme. Some immediate examples that spring to mind involve projects such as the bricking of King William Road, the Victor Harbor rail line, and many more.

Around Australia over 16,000 projects have been federally sponsored. This brings me to one other positive aspect of this project. Projects that are to be considered have support from State government, local government and community organisations. They are projects which are not imposed from Canberra but originate in the community in which they will be built. In this way genuinely felt community needs are catered for and the number of people involved in planning such projects is wide indeed. The performance of the scheme also needs scrutiny. For long term unemployed persons the figures are astounding. For instance, those with nine months or more prior unemployment represent 62 per cent of all CEP placements to date. Over the 1985-86 period this percentage will be around the 77 per cent mark. This remarkable achievement shows clearly that this scheme is getting to the heart of long term unemployment.

One of the other outstanding achievements of this scheme has been its success in meeting the objectives of equal female representation. This was the first major labour force program to take up the challenge of the Government's equal employment opportunity policy. To the end of 1985 the female participation rate was 38.6 per cent. This figure includes the jobs on local roads component, which did not initially have a target for female employment. Should this component be removed then the female participation rate on other projects would rise to 42.7 per cent. During 1985-86 the participation rate will be around 52 per cent. The female component on the local roads project was to be 25 per cent but is actually exceeding that figure by a further 5 per cent. Other persons who have experienced disadvantages in seeking employment have been Aboriginals and migrants with English language difficulties. During the 1985-86 financial year 12 per cent of all placements have been Aboriginals, 14 per cent disabled persons and 10 per cent migrants with English language difficulties.

It would be wrong to suggest that some adjustment problems were not experienced in the early days of this project. Simply to view the whole context of this scheme in terms of just financial resources also poses difficulties. It has been the practice of this Government to try to reach into the morass of long term unemployment and the problems of disadvantaged persons seeking employment. The CEP has achieved remarkable results. In respect of its original terms of reference it has been an outstanding success. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that many honourable senators on this side would disagree that the community employment program is aimed in a very useful direction and has many things going for it. However, the problems as we see them on this side have generally tended to be with the implementation of the program and the manner in which Government money has been spent. The Government has responded to many of the points we have made, particularly those from the coalition Waste Watch Committee, in a way that at best has been unfortunate and at worst misleading and deceptive. The attempts to discredit the Waste Watch Committee's comments on the CEP generally have been along lines that can readily be disproved, and I intend to do so today.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us start with a few general principles. Some of the objections that the Waste Watch Committee has had to the CEP have rested on concerns about the large expenditure of public moneys in areas that, in fact, do not involve employment opportunities to the long term unemployed, in terms of at least providing money to them directly. The concern has tended to be that a large proportion of the CEP money in fact has been directed to areas other than payments for the employment of the long term unemployed. For example, the latest report of the CEP-that is, for its second year, 1984-85-demonstrates that the total value of programs, including sponsor contributions, has been $1,076m and the number of persons placed in employment has been 75,519. In fact, it works out that the average cost of employing each person has been something like $510 a week. Of course, the clear evidence is that people being employed would not be getting anything like $510 a week.

The big question we have been asking is: What has happened to the difference between the $510 a week average cost of each job and the amount, I should imagine, of around $300 a week on average, or perhaps even less in some instances, that the long term unemployed have been receiving? To an extent, of course, that may well be described as not being the Commonwealth's business because some of the money has come from sponsoring groups rather than from the Government itself. Nonetheless, there seems to be enormous scope within the framework of the CEP for Federal money to be directed away from payments to the long term unemployed into other areas. For example, sponsoring organisations in effect can have their immediate ex-staff employed as supervisors in this program. I know of one instance in which an organisation which, from memory, put on three CEP workers had one supervisor paid for by the CEP who was not in fact a long term unemployed person. Not only was she not a long term unemployed person but she had simply ceased employment with the sponsoring organisation immediately before the program started. She had been working for the sponsoring organisation but ceased work for that organisation and became eligible for appointment as a supervisor under CEP, despite the fact that she was not a long term unemployed person-and of course she may have been an ideal person for the job. All I am pointing out is that when employing three long term unemployed people, the sponsoring organisation was able to finance a supervisor out of the funds for the program. Looking at many of these programs--

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to name the project so that we can check your assertion?
—Yes, it is the Wollongong Women's Centre.
—All right, we will check the assertion.

—Thank you. Looking through this list, it seems that many organisations, such as some of the Socialist Workers Party fronts-in which no doubt Senator Cook is interested-which are listed in the mountain of material from the Waste Watch Committee, appear to be able to receive with some ease funds under the program. I am interested to know in how many instances-and we are pursuing this-the people supervising the programs are de facto or ex-members of the sponsoring organisation. That is one element of concern. That example is only one of many of people who have been closely associated with, or are affiliates, members or ex-employees of sponsoring organisations ending up as supervisors of projects or being employed under this scheme, particularly in areas where very few long term unemployed are employed. One supervisor for three long term unemployed people seems to be a rather extraordinary ratio.

SPEECH.PARA: There may well be a case for suggesting to the CEP organisers that where there are as few as two, three or four long term unemployed, the supervisors could be employed on a part-time basis if he or she does not fit the criteria, rather than being paid on a full-time basis. The other area of concern emerges from the guidelines of the CEP, in which part 5.7 states:
Ownership of equipment purchased with grant funds-
Sponsors will be required to specify their intentions to purchase equipment in the grant application forms.
I stress this part:

Any equipment purchased by a sponsor with grant funds will become the property of the sponsor unless the Commonwealth delegate determines otherwise at the time of approval or at any time prior to the completion of the project.

I cite a case in point. An unlicensed Victorian community radio station in the scrub applied for CEP funding to train long term unemployed people in community radio techniques. I will leave to one side the matter of the quality of the training that would emerge as the radio station had no licence, no history and, in fact, was simply seeking to run some trial transmissions. One could question whether that is the ideal centre in which this training should be developed. The CEP organisation agreed to buy for this community radio station, which had basically very little going for it, a console, a turntable and tape recorders so that it would, allegedly, be able to train long term unemployed people. Those assets remained the property of the community radio station after the CEP training program ended. That seems to be a good lark. If one wants to start a community radio station, one offers training and ends up with the Government buying some of the equipment. That is an example of my concern about some of the projects.

I am concerned about other projects that are simply blatantly and disgracefully political, in which money has gone into promoting a political philosophy-a philosophy which, incidentally, may be far to the left of that of the Government. One can hardly say that the Government is being terribly clever in funding this political activity. I assure the Senate that in each instance it is political activity that is aggressively hostile to the Opposition's attitudes. For example, Associate Professor Ted Wheelwright's organisation, the Trans-National Workers Research Group, has done very well out of the program-if not directly, then indirectly. This was through the Printing and Kindred Industries Union grant. I was astounded when I found out how it was ultimately used, because this grant was aimed allegedly at providing $172,644 for research into employment practices. Nine jobs were involved with a duration of 37 weeks for the Printing and Kindred Industries Union to investigate the extent of sub-award employment practices. That works out at about $518 per week per long term unemployed person. There is no way in a fit that any of the long term unemployed involved would have been paid $518 per week. The fair question is what happened to the difference between what they were paid and the amount of the grant? We know where the grant ended up. It is explained in the report `Anti-Union Employment Practices', a final report put out by Professor Ted Wheelwright's Trans-National Corporation with the inevitable introduction from Professor Wheelwright attacking the whole concept of a deregulated labour market, which I notice that some of our colleagues in the Labor Government are tentatively approaching.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—I have been reading large numbers of reports in the newspapers about how various members of the Government and leading members of the Labor movement, such as Mr Charlie Fitzgibbon, have been approaching the view that there is a need for a greater degree of flexibility--
—You have to read exactly what they say before you make assertions.

—Than the backbencher who is interjecting so consistently is prepared to concede. But the introduction to this report is a pretty vicious attack on academic freedom, because Professor Wheelwright says that there is something disgraceful, basically, about a government that provides funds to academic institutions which are not supporting the political position that Professor Wheelwright supports. In fact, the same sort of attitude emerges in the conclusions of this report. The suggestion is that governments should provide funds only to those sorts of research bodies which toe the left wing political line. I must say that I find the diversion of money in this way to be totally offensive. In particular, the nature of this very lengthy attack on the economic and industrial relations policies of the Opposition is way beyond the bounds of what one would be entitled to expect from a grant which is supposed to have gone to providing assistance to the long term unemployed.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, this is only one of the many curious grants that have been given. I do not think I have the time to go through the mountain of material we have involving grants to what are clearly very left wing bodies-groups that are associated, for example, with extreme leftist attitudes in Central America. I understand that FILEF, which receives a grant, is associated with the Italian Communist Party. There is a whole range of most curious organisations apart, of course, from the inevitable collection of peace bodies and so on.

As I said, I was interested to see the nature of the response by the Government to this kind of criticism from the Opposition which I would have thought people like Senator Walsh, who profess a great concern about saving Federal money, would have welcomed. Instead of that, Senator Walsh, for example, attacked the Coalition Waste Watch Committee when it pointed out that money had been directed under CEP towards training people to be clowns. Senator Walsh is on record in the Senate as saying that it was not the present Government that funded people to become clowns, but the previous Government. That, of course, is simply false. Senator Walsh was referring to a project in Gippsland, approval for which was given on 11 November 1983. Even Senator Cook will find it difficult to establish that the Fraser Government could have been involved in decisions to fund a Gippsland clown project on 11 November 1983. That date might have some significance to some honourable senators opposite. However, the significance in this context is that this was many months after March 1983 when the Fraser Government was defeated. It is deceptive and dishonest for anyone in this or any other chamber to get up and say that because this clown training operation was funded by a program initiated by the Fraser Government-the decisions for it in terms of granting money were made entirely by the Hawke Government-this is somehow the responsibility of the Fraser Government. It is deceptive and dishonest to do so.

The simple reality is this: The Fraser Government saved $100m by introducing the wage pause program. The Hawke Government spent the money. It spent it on items such as training people in Gippsland to become clowns. I stress that this kind of response by the Labor Government to clear evidence of this order is, I believe, an indication of the fact that the Waste Watch Committee's exposure of waste and misallocation of money has hit so hard that this Government will deliberately tell lies about allocations of this nature in order to try to discredit the Committee's campaign. The Government will stop at nothing. It will resort to personal denigration, as we have seen in the other House, as part of a concerted political campaign, knowing it to be false.

The Victorian Ministry of Employment and Training's annual report for the year ended 30 June 1984 reveals this training to be a clowns program from the Arts Resources Collective in Gippsland under the wage pause program. As I said, it was announced by the Victorian Government on 11 November 1983, and the amount involved was $85,130. In fact, my records show that the first announcement in Victoria under the wage pause program as administered by the Hawke Government was not, in fact, till some time in May 1983-long after the Fraser Government, which as I said saved money, had been defeated. The administration was then under the Hawke Government. The allocations are under the Hawke Government in association with the Labor Government in Victoria.

I should also say that the clowns training program to which we referred was the one in Canberra. The money allocated to this program was not ultimately spent for one very good reason: By the time it was allocated it was far too late for the program planned by the Arts Council of the Australian Capital Territory to proceed. In other words, the Government in that instance was saved from actually spending the money which it had happily allocated simply because of its own incompetence. Incompetence triumphed over waste. However, let me stress that this Government was happy to see a situation in which people were to be trained to be clowns, whatever the benefit-and that is open to discussion-by allocating something like $410 per week, exempting the cost of the person doing the training, which no doubt would have been an element, and so reducing the average cost to the participants. But the overall cost to them--

TALK.START.PARA: —It didn't happen.

—Exactly, and if the honourable senator had been here he would have heard me explain why. The program did not go ahead because the Government or the people associated with the CEP were too incompetent to get the money out by the time the program was to proceed. The point is that the CEP people were happy for the program to proceed. It was in line with the guidelines. It involved a cost of something like $410 per week per person for people to learn to become clowns. I stress that the Government seems to have an interesting sense of priorities when it pays out a maximum of something like $70 per week under the tertiary education assistance scheme to people at the bottom of the income scale who are learning to become engineers and even lawyers, yet suggests that $410 per week is a reasonable cost to learn to be a clown. That argument is peripheral. The real issues are whether the administration of this scheme has allowed too many opportunities for money to be misdirected and misallocated and whether there is waste. That is the essential point.

SPEECH.PARA: What happens when the programs and projects involve the raising of revenue? One of the matters on which the Government claimed we had been proved to be wrong related to the funding of a conference in Wollongong. It was listed under the program as the first national depressed regions conference. The funding was pretty substantial-$100,624, involving five jobs for 39 weeks. It was to the Wollongong Workers Information Research Centre, to organise the conference. When I put out my Press release, I said that that conference did not ever take place. In fact, it did not take place despite the misleading allegations in this chamber that it did. A conference took place. It was called Australian Industry-the future. Not one item on the agenda related in any way to a conference that could have been vaguely described as the first national depressed regions conference. The words `depressed regions' do not appear on the brochure and, more significantly, there was a charge for participants in this conference the preparation of which was to be funded by CEP. When I asked in a Senate Estimates committee what happens when a charge is made for such a conference, particularly as this involved five people and cost $100,000 to prepare for-it did not ever take place and was replaced by a totally different conference-the response from the Department was as follows:

The project referred to was sponsored by the Wollongong Workers Information and Resource Centre. CEP funds were provided to pay the wages of a co-ordinator for the Centre's activities and part of the co-ordinator's duties was to organise a conference.

Here we have another whimsy about what happens to co-ordinators' pay. In fact, the co-ordinator was supposed to be supervising the five long term unemployed in preparing this conference. This answer is misleading to start off with. The CEP funds were, in fact, provided to pay for five people to prepare for this conference as well as the co-ordinator. But listen to this: While the funds were provided to pay the co-ordinator, part of his duties were to organise a conference but not to actually run it. Funding for the conference itself came from the Wollongong Workers' Information Resource Centre and not from the CEP. In other words, the CEP did all the work, $100,000 worth of work, to prepare for a conference that did not ever take place and which was substituted by another. It did all the work, it paid all the money and it had all the expense. But where does the $5 per head go? Where does the revenue go? It goes instead to the Wollongong Workers Information Resource Centre. I believe there are examples of this order-and we are pursuing them-where money is, in fact, generated from these bodies as a result of work under the CEP and goes to the sponsoring groups. The sponsoring groups involved in this case are not just the Wollongong Workers Information Resource Centre but also the Australian Political Economy Movement and the South Coast Labour Council, that very strong left wing organisation. There are many examples of the way money has been diverted not only from the Government but also from revenue raised as a result of things such as this conference. It has been diverted into the hands of the sponsoring groups either by way of assets, paying the fees of people involved or taking money generated as a result of these projects. This money would never have been generated for the South Coast Labour Council if it had not been for this program.
