TALK.START.PARA: —The Community Employment Amendment Bill 1986 proposes to extend the community employment program for another three years beyond the end of next month. Before I turn to my general remarks on the Bill, I cannot sit back and allow the remarks that have just been made by Senator Michael Baume to go unanswered in some respects. I want to treat some of the things he said in greater detail later, but some threshold rebuttal is necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume asserted that there is widespread maladministration, misadministration or rorts being worked through the CEP. That is the charge he levelled at this Government. He then said, thumbing through an impressive pile of papers, that he had mountains of material to present. We waited in anticipation for this mountain to descend on us. We were given the benefit of two or three examples. Out of a mountain we got two or three examples at great length. Nothing was tabled to show all the other things that he could have referred to but for time-and he pleaded lack of time. No total number for this massive mountain of cases was given, so we do not know what the number is. No percentage of the total number as a proportion of the overall CEP projects was given, so we do not know the incidence of this maladministration. On that basis it can be fairly said that no case has been established despite the assertions and the hyperbole that Senator Michael Baume entertained the Senate with for a few minutes. The case has just not been established. It seemed that Senator Baume's real purpose was to have a go at what he described as left wing groups and to make some political points about his activities in the Illawarra. I suppose many things are fair game in political debate; that is true. That is fair game too. But in the absence of a quantification, in the absence of an incidence table and in the absence of the evidence he asserts exists, one can only draw the conclusion that since he had half an hour to do the job the evidence does not exist. It was never presented. As this debate stands at the moment, I do not think there is much succour for Senator Michael Baume's argument.

I want to go back to the basic problem with which this Government has been contending in the CEP. I want to go back to the years before 1983 when we had galloping unemployment and virtually no prospects for thousands of school leavers in this country. The prime reason why we are sitting on this side of the chamber and members of the coalition are sitting on the other side of the chamber is that they created the greatest unemployment in this country's history. I want to go back to those years for a few minutes. In a public debate about unemployment conservative economists argued that there was an acceptable level of unemployment. They said that the community could bear an acceptable level of unemployment. Politicians such as Malcolm Fraser and John Howard also asserted that there was an acceptable level of unemployment; that we had to tolerate this level of unemployment. Just as long as they were not unemployed but some other poor bugger was, the level of unemployment was acceptable. That became the justification for the level of unemployment applying in this country. The coalition Government's strategy was to fight inflation first, which meant that the unemployed suffered.

The Australian Labor Party, under the Hawke Administration, set out, on taking the treasury bench in the House of Representatives, to fight inflation and unemployment simultaneously. Our whole history as a political party is one of seeking to find the formula for full employment. There is not in the Labor Party lexicon anything that goes remotely close to acceptable levels of unemployment. Our commitment is firmly to full employment. It is not just a commitment, it is deeply embedded in Labor Party philosophy. That is why the wages-prices accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions was worked out. That is why the primary objective of that accord is full employment, and that is why this Government introduced CEP as well. We are committed to getting the macroeconomic settings correct so that, through growth in the economy, all Australians who aspire to jobs will find jobs in rewarding and satisfying careers.

We inherited massive unemployment on a scale that is not easy to turn around and there are no simple panaceas one can produce to solve it. While we pulled the economy out of the morass it was in when we came to office, while we built on a substantial economic growth year on, year on and year on, having expanded the economy for further employment, we introduced CEP to give jobs, work experience, self-esteem and skills to those who were unemployed in this country who had to wait until the macro settings were right before they could move into full employment. That was the strategy we embarked on. It was a humane strategy which reflected our genuine and deep abiding concern for unemployment and it was an effort to do something real and positive for those who suffered the lash of joblessness. Our record on the macro front, which is the most important, is well known, of course.

TALK.START.PARA: —Deplorable.

—Senator Short says it is deplorable. Let me just go back to 1983. In 1983, before coming to office, we promised we would create 500,000 new jobs in our first three years. Liberal politicians said that it could not be done and they rubbished us, saying that it was a promise that was attempting to mislead the Australian community. Back in the 1983 election campaign the Opposition said we could not do it. We did it. We achieved it. In fact, we have created over 600,000 new jobs. That is a substantial achievement of the key promise of the 1983 Hawke election campaign marked `delivered in the community'. We achieved that. We have had year on year of economic growth while in the last year of the Liberal Government there was negative economic growth. Under our administration inflation has come down from the galloping levels it was at under Fraser. Under our administration unit labour costs have been reduced to the levels they were in the 1960s. Under our administration industrial disputes have dropped to decade-long record lows, and under our administration there has been a redistribution of the gross domestic product away from wages and salaries and towards profits.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government initially pursued an expansionary economic philosophy and we are now withdrawing that approach-we have a less expansionary economic approach, in order for the private sector to pick up the slack. We are expecting and hoping that the private sector will invest some of its profits in plant and equipment so that the industrial base of this country can expand and genuine long term jobs created. That is our record. Given that the hecklers opposite said earlier that our record was dismal, if that record is dismal then I am proud to say that I do not mind being called dismal. That is a record of proud achievement, and it is the record of this Government.

I turn to the nature of this Bill. As I said before, it is a Bill which seeks to extend CEP for another three years beyond next month. This year $290m will be allocated to CEP and next year an early indicative amount of $140m will be allocated. We are looking at continuing the program in such a way that, for those who are still unemployed and who are in particularly difficult areas of unemployment, real opportunities will be available through CEP. We expect that there will be 30,000 new jobs this financial year and, because of a carryover from last financial year, 45,000 new jobs will be created in the course of the year. That is the objective and that is the purpose of this legislation.

Having stated that, I want to refer to what I thought was a detailed and studious speech by Senator Graham Maguire earlier in this debate. He analysed the performance of CEP, pointed to the figures, and rebutted some of the specious assertions made by honourable senators on the Opposition benches. One assertion he distinctly and clearly vanquished was an assertion by Senator Vanstone that youth unemployment now was at higher levels than ever before in Australia. Of course, that is just not true, and any resort to the record, to the statistics and to the facts will establish that. I just make the point in passing that, while we have dubious assertions like that that are never backed by any figuring, the general argument that is then put on all the other matters by the people who make those bold assertions is called ultimately and totally into question. In 1986 we are still troubled by the fact that 21.8 per cent of the total number of unemployed are youth unemployed. We say we have not got it right yet but we say that that is 6 per cent less than it was three years ago. This is a difficult problem. We are tackling it responsibly, but there is no automatic panacea. Those figures come down slowly. Our approach is working. It is certainly not true, as Senator Vanstone asserted, that unemployment is at record levels. It is not.

One other point which I think needs to be made is the tendency for the Opposition to want to have it both ways. That tendency is most marked when it comes to announcing CEP initiatives in Liberal Party electorates. Under the guidelines, local members are notified when CEP programs are approved. I have never noticed any marked reluctance by any member of the Liberal Party-or member of the National Party of Australia, for that matter-to rush into print and claim the credit for a particular CEP program. There is no reluctance at the coal face of the electorate in that regard. There is also no reluctance in this chamber to bag CEP up hill and down dale, as we heard from Senator Michael Baume-the old `let us have it both ways' approach. I suppose many things go in politics, but that type of hypocrisy ought to be noted. CEP is a Labor Government initiative; those jobs would not have been created without it. Because CEP responds to community needs, it is often the case that the local member claiming credit for certain projects had nothing to do with those projects. I might also say that it is sometimes the case that the local member had something to do with the particular project. In those circumstances the local member is to be commended for taking advantage of a project aimed at creating work for unemployed people in that particular electorate who are in desperate conditions, and in particular cases of discrimination those areas concerning women, Aborigines, disabled people and migrants who do not have an easy facility with the English language.

The next point I move to is the general point of this debate. It has been made by a number of Opposition senators and, while it is trivial in its content, it has been the major expression of view by them and it requires nailing. I refer to the argument that CEP is in some way being abused or misused. Senator Michael Baume said it is blatantly and disgracefully political. As I said at the beginning of my speech, Senator Michael Baume made those assertions but he did not table any documents to indicate the incidence of `blatantly and disgracefully political' programs. He cited one or two cases and then, on the basis of the dubious examples he used, he bagged the whole scheme-a scheme which has created 100,000 jobs in Australia. I do not think that that argument can stand up.

I want to go back and look at the record. Many of the projects that were attacked by Senator Michael Baume had their origins in the wage pause program. That program was initiated not by this Government but by the former Government. We inherited it, and we were obliged to observe the guidelines that had been laid down and the commitments entered into by the former government with the States. What happened under that program is not our responsibility. It was our responsibility to carry it through. Since it was not originated by us and we were not responsible for drawing up the guidelines, we cannot now be attacked for the deficiencies that it had-and, indeed, it had deficiencies.

Senator Michael Baume referred to two or three cases. I have a list of 20 projects funded under the wage pause program. The organisations which were beneficiaries could have been regarded as political. If Senator Michael Baume wants to attack the CEP, which is a Labor Government initiative, because some groups which he considers politically distasteful may have got some advantage from it, he ought to look at what advantage was achieved in the same sense under the Liberal program and accept that many more projects than those he chose to rely on have received the same succour in terms of the injection of funds for job creation.

A fundamental point that seems to have escaped every speaker in this debate is that in order to get a program funded under the CEP one has to prepare a program submission and submit it to a broadly-based community-selected committee. The committee receives all the incoming submissions and applies stringent criteria to them, assesses them and then makes decisions according to what funds are available and according to the priority in job creation. The commitment is to job creation, particularly in those areas in the work force where there is discrimination. So any attack upon a CEP allocation is, in reality, not an attack upon this Government but an impugning of the integrity of the community groups that make up the CEP committees and make those allocations. If anything in this debate is disgraceful it is that impugning of the genuine integrity of the broadly-based selection committees. I do not know what is the purpose in launching this attack. I do not know whether it is to discourage people from offering public service to the community by volunteering to accept an appointment to those committees. If that be the purpose, it is genuinely disgraceful.

We take responsibility as a government for setting the guidelines, which are indeed stringent. We take responsibility as a government for entering into exhaustive community consultation. We take responsibility as a government for making the funds available. We take responsibility as a government for targeting the hardship groups that need to be served. We take responsibility as a government for the global aspects of the program. But the administration of the direct allocations is overwhelmingly in the hands of the community groups, who take that responsibility. The criticism that has been made ought to be seen as an unjustified criticism of those groups.

I have said that under the wage pause program, which was a lax and maladministered program because of the guidelines that the Fraser Government had laid down, I could list 20 projects. The list is too long to read at this hour of the debate. Let me refer to a couple of the more interesting projects. Under the Fraser program, the Amalgamated Metal Foundry and Shipwrights Union of New South Wales obtained a grant of $32,904. An Italian organisation, FILEF in New South Wales, received $11,800 for the production of an Italian language newspaper. I think that is the organisation that Senator Michael Baume attacked as being an extreme left wing organisation. Going down the list, the Association for Peace Studies in Victoria received $24,000. Friends of the Earth in Western Australia received $10,900 and $28,600, and so on. Senator Michael Baume gave two or three examples. I have 20, and I am prepared to table my list. I do not know where that takes us, because the basic purpose of both programs is to create more jobs. Our program is properly audited, checked and scrutinised. The wage pause program was not. That is a deficiency that we have had to live with. The result is that as an outcome of both of these programs more Australians in need have got work.

It seems to me that the real point Senator Michael Baume wanted to make was to use the debate on the community employment program to attack various left wing radical groups, and he described some groups, such as the Socialist Workers Party, as being antagonistic to Labor government. Anyone in the Labor Party knows what it is like to be criticised by those groups who claim to be holier than the Labor Party in their concern and compassion for the broader community. If such groups meet the criteria of the guidelines and they propose a genuine job creation program, in a pluralist society they have a right to their individual political points of view. The question here is not what might be the political point of view of some group in the broader community which applies for and gets a community employment program grant because it meets the standards; the question is whether it is proposing a genuine job creation program. I think that the political intolerance of the Opposition in saying that some groups should be censored and discriminated against because of their political views, which is the import of Senator Michael Baume's remarks, is distasteful.

To balance the ledger, I shall refer to a particular community employment program project that was approved by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis). The weight of Senator Michael Baume's attack has been that only left wing groups benefit. I have in front of me a community employment Commonwealth component project summary document. The project's sponsor is the National Library of Australia and the project title is `Liberal Party of Australia Records Project'. The description of the project under the heading `Project Aim and Activities' reads:

A large body of Liberal Party records totalling several hundred boxes, was identified, labelled and prepared for relocation in appropriate archival containers. Much of this material had previously been stored loose on shelves. The material is now housed in conditions which will prevent its physical deterioration and is so identified that it can be made readily available to scholars. This is an important collection of major political and historical importance.

The project was timed to commence in December 1984 and had to be completed by 13 February 1985. Total funding was $6,500. I have talked about our society being a pluralist society, tolerant of all strands of political view. If a Labor government were to take the view that Senator Michael Baume was espousing, it could have said: `Because this project preserves records that our political enemies have developed over the years, we will not fund it. They can just forget about it. We will not provide any assistance to the Liberal Party'. But this Government did fund that project, and that was done at ministerial level. I want that firmly on the record, because with the modern McCarthyism with which Senator Michael Baume is associating himself, it ought to be squarely on the record in this debate that this Labor Government has recognised the pluralistic nature of our community. It has ensured that, irrespective of the political viewpoint that might be held or served by a particular project, the fundamental and critical aspect is whether it fulfils these criteria: Does it create jobs? Will it provide experience for people in the community who would otherwise not get work? Will it provide self-esteem for the longer term unemployed? Will it make a meaningful contribution to the community in some valuable way? Will it fit people with some work experience which will give them better prospects for full, enduring, lifelong careers in the future? Those are the basic criteria which we have addressed and that is the performance of the community employment program.

A total of $1,035.74m has been spent on the CEP, 18,272 projects have been funded and more than 100,000 people have got work. That is the record of the CEP. At the National Economic Summit Conference in 1983 the Government introduced our program on unemployment and identified our approach as being not `fight inflation first' but `fight inflation and unemployment simultaneously'. Neville Wran summarised our objectives in three words-`jobs, jobs, jobs'. The community employment program has addressed that and is delivering. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a few points in this debate on the Community Employment Amendment Bill 1986. The first thing that should be stressed is that, contrary to the implications in the remarks of Senator Cook and other speakers on the Government side, the Opposition is not opposing this Bill to extend the community employment program by a further three years. We are not opposing the legislation, but we are saying that there are some very serious defects which have been revealed by the scheme to date and which the Government must address if it wants to be seriously considered as having the interests of the unemployed of this country really at heart.

SPEECH.PARA: Before addressing the Bill, let me pick up a few of the points made by Senator Cook, because they were grossly misleading about unemployment, inflation and job creation in this country. First, I point out that the Hawke Government's unemployment record to date compares very badly with that of the Fraser Government during its seven years in office. Senator Cook said that the Australian Labor Party was seeking a formula for full employment. He said that `jobs, jobs, jobs' was the real theme of the Labor Government. If that is so, it is about time the Government went back to the drawing board in order to try to meet its objectives. The Hawke Government has been in power for 37 months. The Fraser Government was in power for 86 months. If one compares the unemployment record of the two governments, one finds that unemployment has been higher during the 37 months of the Hawke Government than it was in all but four of the 86 months of the Fraser Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!
—Senator Evans may laugh, but the statistics are there for all to see.
—Lies, damned lies and statistics.

—The Government's unemployment record does not compare with that of the Fraser Government. The Government has talked at length about the jobs it has created since it came to office in 1983. I remind Government speakers that there has been job creation in the past three years for three main reasons: First, the Government came to office right at the time when the American and other international economies began to take off again in a growth phase; secondly, the Government came to office literally on the day the drought broke; and, thirdly, it came to office inheriting a wage pause program that had been agreed between the previous Fraser Government and the trade union movement. The Government very wisely continued that program for the initial nine months of its term.

SPEECH.PARA: Those three factors more than anything else caused the creation of jobs. Even with all that luck running for it, the Government's record on job creation does not compare favourably with that of the Fraser Government. As Senator Cook said in an intervention a few moments ago, I suppose one can have lies, damned lies and statistics; but I can show honourable senators opposite several three-year periods during the Fraser Government's term of office during which the numbers of new jobs created far exceeded the achievements about which the Hawke Government is now trumpeting.

Senator Cook also talked about inflation and the inflation record of this Government. I remind him of the inflation record of this Government. Our inflation rate, relative to that of other countries-that is the key criterion because it determines the competitiveness of our country in the international market-place, and that competitiveness in turn is the real determinant of long term growth and employment in any nation-is 2.4 times higher than that of the average of other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. That record has not been surpassed since the OECD was formed. In other words, we now have the worst inflation record, relative to our major trading partners and other Western countries, that we have ever had. There again, the Hawke Government's record is appalling in the key area for looking at the engine of growth on a sustainable basis in any economy.

Yet we wonder why there is a lack of investment in this country at the moment. The Government, the Opposition and industry itself are concerned by the lack of growth in private investment, which is the engine house for future growth in our economy. Why is investment not occurring at a desirable rate in this country? Basically, it is because the potential investors are so concerned about the direction in which the Hawke Government is leading this country's economy over the next two or three years, which is when the return on investment will be reaped, that they are not game to put their money in at this stage. On all those very fundamental points the record of this Government is appalling.

I return to the main purpose of this debate-the Community Employment Amendment Bill 1986. In August 1983, with the aid of a $500,000 publicity campaign, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) launched the community employment program. Its aim was to help the most disadvantaged unemployed to gain self-esteem and improve their permanent job prospects. That was a very laudable aim with which the Opposition fully agreed and still agrees. In announcing in December 1985 the extension of the CEP for a further three years, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, claimed that by the end of 1985-86 some 18,500 projects and about 118,500 job opportunities will have been provided. At a cost of $1.12 billion from Commonwealth funds in addition to sponsor contributions, the total cost for the three years 1983 to 1986 could be well over $1.3 billion. That is an enormous commitment of taxpayers' money to a scheme which, whilst laudable in its intent, I believe has several serious defects which I urge the Government to look at as a matter of urgency if we are going to get value for money as taxpayers and if the intended beneficiaries of the scheme are to derive the benefit that we would all wish them to get. I will come to some specific suggestions on that matter later in my remarks.

The Opposition supported the initiative in 1983; we said then, however, that we had doubts that it was the best way to tackle long term unemployment. Nevertheless, it has provided some amelioration for a number of people. But more opportunities for growth in employment will, of course, only eventuate from proper overall economic management in terms of fiscal and monetary policy and, very importantly, in the area of wages policy.

I believe that our criticisms of the Government's proposals in 1983 have now proven valid. It is an enormously costly program. As I said, the total estimated cost to date is over $1.3 billion, and presumably at least that amount again will be spent over the next three years. It has achieved only limited success. More than 50 per cent of participants in the scheme were not in permanent employment six months after ending their CEP jobs. There is evidence that the Government is using the scheme to finance, in many cases, its favourite left wing causes and to reward its friends. For example-I will not go into all the details as they have been gone into by others-many CEP projects have gone to or involved trade unions. That has happened at a time when the funds of the 20 largest trade unions in this country totals $118m. That represents an increase of 550 per cent in union funds over the last ten years. Despite that enormous increase in the coffers of the unions, the Government has continued to put large amounts of taxpayers' money through CEP and other programs into the trade unions.

Another criticism made at the time on which I think we have been proven correct is that the average duration of unemployment has not been reduced as a result of CEP. The average duration of unemployment is now 52 weeks, compared with 40 weeks in early 1983, just before CEP was introduced. So long term unemployment has increased; it has not improved. The latest unemployment figures indicate an increase in the rate of youth unemployment. The cost per job provided under CEP has been estimated at being in excess of $500 a week-a very large amount of money. Of course, only a fraction of that actually gets to the unemployed participant in the scheme.

In the Canberra Times on 18 November 1983 the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) trumpeted that Australia's employment situation was expected to have improved over the next three years to such an extent that job creation schemes such as the CEP would be abolished. Yet, three and a bit years later, we have the Labor Government touting the CEP program as a great success and saying that it will continue with it virtually unaltered for a further three years. It seems to smack of a smug complacency and a seeming inability by the Government to perceive the scheme's faults. Our criticism of what the Government is proposing with this extension is not the fact that it is being extended but that it is being extended without sufficient attention being paid to the problems that have emerged in its experience over the last three years.

In addition, we now have a youth traineeship scheme which was also launched in a blaze of publicity. This scheme is yet to provide any significant jobs or traineeships. There have been some, but they have been of a very insignificant nature and virtually all of them have been in the public sector. The job creation ability of this Government, quite frankly, is a myth. Labor seems to be more interested in self-promotion than in providing real assistance to the unemployed. The net result of the self-aggrandisement and ego-tripping by the Prime Minister and his Ministers is that the unemployed are being very cruelly conned by government statements which the Government knows full well it cannot deliver on.
When announcing the extension of CEP for a further three years in December 1985 Mr Willis said:
. . . the Government is prepared to consider any changes which would clearly result in further improvements to the program's achievements.

It is in the spirit of that promise by the Government that I wish to make some contributions in this debate. My first query is whether the Hawke Government has learnt not only from the mistakes that have been revealed by CEP in its first three years but also, going back even further, from the very real mistakes that emerged with what was to some extent the forerunner of the CEP program back in the mid-1970s, namely, the old regional employment development scheme, which the Whitlam Government introduced. That Government found subsequently that it was so full of holes that it announced its abandonment just before it went out of government in 1975. There is in existence a report prepared after the abandonment of the RED scheme by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations on the substantial misuse of funds under the scheme and the way projects were approved for political reasons against its own guidelines. I suggest to Mr Willis that if he has not already done so, he should hunt up this report and learn its lessons. He appears not to have done so in any shape or form. The CEP scheme of the Hawke Government is now showing signs of being a tragic re-run of the RED scheme fiasco of the Whitlam Government.

I urge the Minister to take heed of the warning signs in CEP and to spend more of his time monitoring the program, which is in danger of becoming a bureaucratic nightmare and a fiasco. There is strong evidence gathered over a long period to indicate that the scheme is being abused by certain political operators-certainly not all; I am not suggesting that-and others to the detriment of those whom it was originally designed to help. Many of these examples have been outlined in debate in this chamber and in the other chamber. I will not go into them again other than just to mention yet again the disastrous debacle that has overtaken one of the major schemes in Victoria, namely, the Footscray swimming centre project. It is a project on which I am still waiting for much further information from the Minister.

The Minister must act to pull CEP into line. I would like to raise six specific criticisms and concerns. The first relates to the design of the program. Is CEP tailored to meet the needs of the long term unemployed? Secondly, are CEP funds merely an alternative source of funding for local and State governments, or are they really designed to try to tackle the problem of unemployment? Thirdly, are the monitoring techniques being adopted under the program effective? What action has been taken when abuses are detected? Will the Minister make audits of schemes public? Fourthly, why are so many politically active groups being sponsored? Fifthly, are the current guidelines for sponsors comprehensive enough? Sixthly, is the growing use of project managers deliberate? What are the implications of this very important extension of project manager use? I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
