TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that Senator Button will be absent from the chamber for Question Time today. Any questions normally directed to Senator Button in relation to his portfolio or those he represents should be directed to me.

—In the absence of Senator Button, my question is addressed not to Senator Grimes, whose grasp of social security matters I suspect is greater than that of interest rates but is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does he agree with the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia, Mr Bob Johnston, who said on Wednesday that, even on optimistic assumptions, large current account deficits may be with us for some time? I was going to ask Senator Button that question because his published views on the J curve suggest that he would agree with Mr Johnston. Does the Minister share Mr Johnston's concern that, because of the serious trade account problem, monetary policy may be called on to play a greater role than would be desirable? What implications does this have for interest rates in the medium to long term?

—I do not think that people who hold important positions, or positions that are perceived to be important, anyway, ought to be speculating about the likely direction of interest rates at all. I remember one person who certainly held an important position a few years ago, a person named Anthony, who was Deputy Prime Minister at the time, saying that interest rates would fall by 2 per cent over the course of the year or he would eat his hat. The Prime Minister at the time said something similar and gave an absolute guarantee that interest rates would fall by 2 per cent, or something. I do not think that people ought to speculate about the likely movement of interest rates. Of course, it remains a question of received wisdom, I suppose, that tight monetary policy equals higher interest rates than if there were not a tight monetary policy.

—I have a supplementary question. I ask the Minister, in light of that quite peculiar reply, whether he agrees that elements of both Government policy and Reserve Bank activity impact upon interest rates. Does he suggest that questions about the likely impact of specific Government policies on interest rates generally are not questions which should be addressed? I ask him again: Does he share Mr Johnston's concern that, given our very serious trade account problem, monetary policy may well be called upon to play a greater role than he as the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer would regard as desirable? Further, does he agree that the implications are that this will continue to exert an upward pressure on interest rates?

—I am not trying to be evasive. Senator Chaney said something like this: `Does Government policy impact on interest rates?'. Of course Government policy impacts on interest rates; all sorts of things impact on interest rates. Having said that, one should avoid being too simplistic about this, as politicians in the past have been known to be simplistic-indeed, not only politicians. It was a popular thing in a discredited former Government to say that there was a direct correlation between the size of the Commonwealth Budget deficit and the level of interest rates. That has been empirically disproven in both directions since that was the conventional wisdom of the Fraser Government. Again, as an accurate generalisation, of course a current account deficit, as distinct from a Budget deficit, which some people confuse, of the size that Australia has at present and has had for a number of years-indeed, it is worth noting that the highest ever recorded current account deficit as a proportion of gross domestic product was the 6.1 per cent recorded in 1981-82 when Mr Howard was the Treasurer--
—What will this year's be?

—This year's will not be 6.1 per cent of GDP. If it were 6.1 per cent of this year's GDP, it would be something close to $14 billion. The highest current account deficit we have ever had, at least since reliable statistics have been kept, was in 1981-82 when Mr Howard was Treasurer. Of course, current account deficits among other things, through various linkages, are likely to exert upward pressures on interest rates.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Was there a shortfall in the offsets due to Australia through the procurement of defence items from overseas companies in the years 1970 to 1984 and what was the order of that shortfall? What action is the Government taking to ensure that Australia receives the best offsets deals possible in such procurements; for example, from the company that received the contract for the new helicopter acquisition announced yesterday? In what way does the revised offsets policy benefit Australian industry and the Australian economy generally?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Elstob asked me about a shortfall in offsets between 1970 and 1984. Certainly it is the case that between those years there was an apparent shortfall in the offsets due to Australian industry of some $420m against defence purchases. I say `apparent' because $380m of that was attributable to the FA18 project, which at the time had achieved little progress. We had firm contractual commitments to provide these offsets, but the time for achievement extended into the 1990s. This particular program has since maintained its schedule, producing about $100m worth of offsets to date, including technology transfers and work for Australian industry. The long timeframe involved is a characteristic of defence programs, reflecting their complexity and size, and should not be necessarily interpreted as an inability to obtain firm contractual obligations or fulfilment of those obligations.

ANSWER.PARA: The present Government, unlike its predecessors, has been absolutely assiduous in its pursuit of offsets arrangements of this kind. With regard to the kind of action the Government is currently taking, the Government advises prospective tenderers of the Government's policy on offsets and encourages the offer not just of the mandatory minimum but of more than that. We do this by making the value and quality of Australian industry involvement, including offsets, factors to be assessed in the evaluation of the tenderers. That was certainly taken into account in respect of the helicopter exercise to which Senator Elstob referred.

As to the general benefits that flow from offsets, I guess it is fairly obvious that the revised offsets policy adopted by this Government aims to acquire advanced technology, skills and capabilities which would support industry objectives for defence and would result in the establishment and enhancement of internationally competitive facilities in Australia. I repeat that this Government has a very strong commitment to the offsets program; one that is being worked out and stands in stark contrast to the lack of commitment reflected in the figures of our tory predecessors.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Finance recall his answer to my questions at the hearings of Estimates Committee C when he admitted that the Government was considering changing the present system of appeals against taxation assessments? Does this involve the informal and effective Taxation Boards of Review under the present system being subsumed into the legalistic and impersonal Administrative Appeals Tribunal? What guarantees will the Minister provide that taxpayers will not be disadvantaged by any change, or have their rights reduced in the event of such a change being introduced?

—I do recall the question coming up at Estimates Committee C. I do not recall precisely what I said but it certainly was along the lines that the Government has before it a proposition to change the administrative arrangements for taxation appeals. That has not yet been finalised. Some of the other points that Senator Messner raised I think deserve two comments. First, he seems to assume that anything that makes appeal processes more legalistic will be to the disadvantage of taxpayers as individuals. I think it is a pretty strange conclusion to come to, if anyone looked at the record of the High Court of Australia in this area. Through the 1970s and in the era when it was dominated by Barwick it came out with so many ludicrous decisions that tax paying virtually became a voluntary activity in Australia. Indeed, my own view is that the less the lawyers are allowed to have to do with that area, probably the better-maybe the less influence the lawyers are allowed to have in other areas, the better as well.
—Especially in Cabinet.

—I am not going to go into that with Senator Withers, who is a former lawyer and Cabinet Minister. The other point concerns this notion of what advantages or disadvantages a taxpayer. There is a quite widespread and popular view-it is not confined to the Opposition-that any institution or administrative arrangement which `protects' the perceived rights of the individual against the tyranny of the state is a good thing. When that is applied to taxation matters or, for that matter, to expenditure matters, it ought to be borne in mind that the state is no more than the sum of the individuals within it and that any arrangement, policy or whatever that provides particular advantages for an individual is achieved at the expense of all the other individuals who comprise the state.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I hear what the Minister says, in his usual bombastic manner, but could we have a simple answer to whether the Government is contemplating a change to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, as I outlined?
—I have already said that. The Government has under consideration at the moment a review of taxation appeal mechanisms but that that has not yet been finalised.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I refer the Minister to recent events in the United States of America where medical products such as tablets and capsules have been illegally tampered with. I ask: What action has the Government taken to ensure that similar products in Australia cannot be tampered with in this way?

—As Senator Zakharov implies, there have been considerable problems in the United States with people tampering with capsules in particular. In fact, in the worst cases cyanide was introduced into the capsules of a very frequently used analgesic in the United States. There have been efforts over many years, even preceding what happened in the United States, by companies to introduce tamper resistant packaging in this country and other countries. The Proprietary Association of Australia, whose members produce about 90 per cent of the over-the-counter preparations, has set a deadline for the introduction of tamper resistant packaging, and most preparations will be protected by February 1987. Certainly, the balance will be protected by August 1987. The moves towards tamper resistant packaging, the existence of emergency procedures, and the methods that will be used have not been publicised and will not be publicised by us, on police advice, for the simple reason that we do not want publicity encouraging cranks to find ways of circumventing such procedures. I can assure the honourable senator that the universal introduction of tamper resistant packages is proceeding as we thought it would and will be complete next year.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINAL ENTERPRISE DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS: SOUTH QUEENSLAND

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Is the Minister aware that unless urgent action is taken by the Aboriginal Development Commission four enterprise development projects-Alcorn College, Brisbane; Almavale stud, Toowoomba; the picture theatre at Mitchell; and the cultural centre at Southport-will be lost to the Aboriginal people of south Queensland? Has the Minister yet responded to urgent requests from south-east Queensland Aboriginal representatives for his intervention and support in a situation which is severely disadvantaging Aboriginals in south Queensland? If the Minister has responded, has he acted in support of these people and, if not, when will he do so and in what way?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Holding has advised me that he has responded today on the matters raised by Senator Macklin in his question. Although I do not intend to go into detail about the Minister's response I do have some background information about the matters addressed in Senator Macklin's question. The allegations have been brought to the Minister's attention. He understands that they claim that south-east Queensland is receiving significantly smaller proportions of grant moneys from the ADC by comparison with other areas. I should mention that the ADC operates under its governing legislation as a self-managing Aboriginal organisation and, as such, the role of the ADC commissioners is to consider the needs of Aboriginals nationally in their allocation of loans and grants for lands, enterprises and housing fund. To suggest that the Aboriginal Development Commission is not performing its job satisfactorily goes to the very heart of and undermines the very basis of the principle of Aboriginal self-management.

ANSWER.PARA: The facts are that only 30 per cent of Queensland Aboriginal people live in south Queensland. In regard to land and enterprise funding the ADC has allocated $8.04m since 1981-82, of which $887,000 has been allocated to south Queensland. Projects worth approximately a further $2m for south Queensland currently are under consideration by the Commission and these are expected to receive attention at the June meeting of the Board of Commissioners. An amount of $25.937m in housing loans has been allocated to south Queensland since 1975, compared to $3.855m for north Queensland. A total of $3.063m has been allocated to south Queensland under the grants in aid program for housing, compared to an amount of $5,672m for north Queensland in 1985-86. I am sure Senator Macklin will agree that these figures indicate a very favourable result for south Queensland on a per capita basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations whether he has seen a report in the Courier-Mail on the Opposition's industrial relations platform headlined `Coalition outlines Queensland-style industrial policy'? In view of the fact that the Queensland legislation has led to Queensland having the highest rate of industrial disputes and bankruptcy growth in the country, the highest level of unemployment of any mainland State, and the nation's lowest average weekly earnings, can the Minister predict the outcome if the Federal coalition is ever in a position to inflict Queensland style industrial relations policies on the rest of the country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Black's question draws attention to the fact that the economic performance of Queensland is dragging down the rest of Australia; that the national economic performance is worse than it would otherwise be because of the Queensland Government. It may be drawing too long a bow to say that that is entirely attributable to the industrial relations policies of the Queensland Government, but I think it is quite reasonable to say that a factor in the dismal economic performance of Queensland is the industrial relations practices in that State, certainly as reflected in the fact that Queensland has the highest level of industrial disputes of any State.

ANSWER.PARA: The real point of Senator Black's question is whether I could predict what would happen if a Federal coalition should be installed and attempted to apply the same sort of policy nationally, as indeed the Federal coalition threatens to do. I think the answer to that really is fairly self-evident: The national economy would be performing at a level closer to that of the Queensland economy than it is at the present level, and that would be a good deal less satisfactorily than it is performing now. Indeed, the chief architect of the sort of industrial relations policy the Opposition was said to have favoured-although perhaps in view of the release of the policy yesterday there is some doubt as to whether the policy Mr Howard said he favoured is still the policy of the Opposition-he said gleefully would lead to what he called, and gleefully anticipated, five years of industrial warfare. He said that he looked forward to having five years of industrial warfare. He might look forward to it but I do not think many other people would-certainly not the people in this Government nor, I would have thought, at least half the members of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wished to direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate but, as it has an element of finance and an element of primary industry, I will direct it to the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. I refer the Minister to today's Financial Times which states that the Government is on the verge of offering an $84m package to the heavy engineering industries. In light of that offer and the generous grant of $350m to assist the steel industry and the car industry, will the Minister explain why his Government blatantly discriminates against the sugar industry which effectively has been given $63m in assistance over three years, or slightly over $20m a year, when his Government promised a $150m package? Will he advise the sugar farmers to affiliate with the Australian Council of Trade Unions as that is the only way to get this Government to give assistance? Will the Minister agree that his Government is pork-barrelling the industries with large union membership at the instruction of the ACTU while ignoring the plight of the sugar industry and other primary industries that do not have ACTU affiliation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be noted for the record that Senator Boswell is opposed to assistance for the heavy engineering industries. He wants to see Tofts Engineering Pty Ltd in Bundaberg closed down, the north Queensland--
—Mr President, I take a point of order. The Minister misrepresents me. At no stage did I say that I was opposed to assistance--
—Order! There is no point of order.
—The honourable senator wants to see the North Queensland shipping yards in Cairns closed down and the Massey-Ferguson (Aust) Ltd cane harvester factory closed down.

ANSWER.PARA: Government senators-Shame!

TALK.START.PARA: —It is indeed shameful that an honourable senator who purports to represent Queensland wants to see all those major industries closed down. Of course, there are many more that I cannot recall at the moment. Senator Boswell referred to a report, if I heard him correctly, in the Financial Times. I suppose that he meant the Australian Financial Review. I have not had time to read it this morning. I have not seen that report. I will return to the other point of his question. It contained two real points. One was that he wants to see the heavy engineering industry in Queensland and everywhere else closed down, and the other concerned sugar.

ANSWER.PARA: There are at least two reasons why the Government has taken up the policy that it has regarding underwriting assistance for the sugar industry. The first is that a major cause of the problems of the sugar industry is the fact that it has been regimented by the Queensland Government for decades in a manner which has prevented the industry from achieving the economies of scale for which its technical efficiency provides the potential. Secondly, the industry is almost entirely confined to Queensland. If it is not unique in that regard, it is almost unique. I said `almost entirely confined to Queensland' deliberately because a small part of the industry, about one per cent, is located in New South Wales. Instead of berating the Commonwealth Government for its generous offer to the sugar industry, Senator Boswell ought to berate the State Government of Queensland for failing to do what the New South Wales Government has done-match the Commonwealth contribution, $1 for $2, in the way that the Commonwealth required. The New South Wales Government has agreed to match the Commonwealth contribution in the required manner; the Queensland Government has not. The Government out of the three governments involved which has something to answer for is the Queensland Government, not the Commonwealth Government or the New South Wales Government. We also know that Queensland's Minister for Primary Industries, Mr Turner, agrees with the Commonwealth about this matter. The Queensland agriculture Minister wants to match the Commonwealth's offer in the way the Commonwealth requires but, as Mr Kerin said, Mr Turner gets cut off at the knees every time by the Premier of Queensland. It is about time that the Queensland people and those in Senator Boswell's Party started thinking about getting rid of that vexatious geriatric who cuts Mr Turner off at the knees--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the Minister to withdraw that remark.
—I am sorry, Mr President. I withdraw that. The Queensland Premier cuts Mr Turner off at the knees and prevents the sugar industry from receiving the assistance which the Commonwealth has offered.

—I ask the Minister for Resources and Energy: Given the shocking disaster at the Chernobyl reactor involving what seems to have been a partial meltdown and the appalling record of radiation leakages and accidents on board both the United States and Soviet ships and submarines to which I referred in my speech yesterday, will the Minister inform the Senate what plans exist in the event of a reactor accident in Western Australia, where many United States nuclear-powered warships come on port calls? Does the Minister believe that in light of the dangers from nuclear power and when the experts clearly have no idea how to handle a serious accident, Australia should follow the example of New Zealand and ban all nuclear-powered and nuclear-armed warships from our ports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's position on access by nuclear-capable ships and nuclear-powered ships to Australian ports is perfectly well known. Nothing that has happened in the Soviet Union in the last week, let alone anything that may have been said by Senator Vallentine in her speech yesterday, has led the Government to reconsider that position. However, I will explain with some precision what the situation is on visits of nuclear-powered warships to Australian ports to set at rest any fears that might be held as a result of agitation from those such as Senator Vallentine who want to make capital out of the tragedy at Chernobyl and to make clear that there is no ground for concern as far as our existing procedures are concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: Nuclear-power warship visits to Australia must take place in accordance with the conditions of entry which were first laid down in 1976, reviewed in 1982 and affirmed by me in the Senate on 15 December 1983. The condition relevant to safety planning is that an operating safety organisation, competent to conduct a suitable radiation-monitoring program and able to initiate actions and provide services necessary to safeguard the public in the event of a release of radioactivity following an accident, must exist for the port being visited. That is the basic rule. The way that it applies is that each Australian port which has been assessed as being suitable on environmental and safety grounds to host nuclear-powered warship visits has a safety plan designed to address all aspects of routine and emergency matters associated with them. This plan is prepared and, where necessary, implemented by a State or Territory nuclear-powered warship visits committee which includes representatives from the police, emergency services, port authorities, health and environmental organisations.

There are about another eight or nine points, Mr President. It is quite a lengthy answer. I do not know whether Senator Vallentine wants me to go on, or whether she would be happy for me to incorporate it in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Please go on.

—The honourable senator does not give me leave to incorporate it, so I will proceed. The committee liaises with appropriate local and Commonwealth authorities. The latter assists in the provision of overall guidelines and advises on safety plans, radiation monitoring assistance, and co-ordination through the National Disasters Organisation of any additional Commonwealth support that is necessary. Safety plans vary in accordance with local conditions and administrative arrangements. However, they generally include arrangements for radiation monitoring and protection, co-ordination of emergency services, evacuation, public information and the removal of the vessel to a remote safe location.

ANSWER.PARA: Nuclear weapons accidents are managed within the general control of emergency plans for accidents involving warships. This is undertaken in the knowledge that safety precautions taken on board visiting warships effectively preclude the possibility of an accidental nuclear detonation and that our main concern is the release of radioactive material from other causes, such as fire. The responsibility for such plans rests in the first instance with the port authorities, naval or civil. These are integrated into and supported by State and Territory emergency services, with Commonwealth support if necessary. Every port in Australia is covered by such arrangements.

These plans generally provide for a graduated response relying in the first instance on the safety design features and crew expertise available in modern warships. Should this be insufficient, the resources of the port emergency service, with its State, Territory and Commonwealth support, are utilised. The emergency procedures adopted would be generally similar to those that I described a moment ago for nuclear-powered warships. I would emphasise that there is a specific requirement for captains of vessels to inform port authorities immediately of an accident or incident involving a nuclear weapon or a nuclear reactor. The incident would also be reported immediately to the home base of the visiting vessel, and we would expect appropriate assistance to be provided.

I would also emphasise once again that these plans address a remote contingency. While a wide range of foreign warships, including nuclear-powered warships, have visited Australia, there has never been an accident involving the weapons or the nuclear propulsion systems on board these vessels while in an Australian port. The radiation monitoring procedures activated by Australia during nuclear-powered warship visits have never revealed any leakage of radiation from any of these vessels.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has not given an answer about exactly what the emergency procedures are. It is very difficult to obtain this information from the State authorities. Why are such plans secret if people need to know what to do in the case of an emergency? How can they be expected to know what to do if such plans are secret? There would be absolute and total chaos in the case of an accident.

—I believe that I have given a great deal of information in the course of my answer today. If there is any other information that the Minister for Defence feels able to provide to Senator Vallentine along the lines she has indicated, I will bring it to his attention in order that he can make that decision.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. With the reduction in revenue to government due to the downturn in oil prices, certain changes to the tax package and, in the words used by Senator Button earlier, some of the effects of the fringe benefits tax being highly speculative, will the Government still provide personal tax reductions as promised and in accordance with the program as previously scheduled?

—As far as I know, the answer to that is yes, but I will refer the question to the Treasurer for confirmation. I want to make one point arising from the question. Senator Watson referred to the reduction in oil revenues. It is true that there is some reduction in revenue because of the falling oil price. I cannot recall off the top of my head just what the estimate for that is for next year. The honourable senator referred also to other questions about the tax package. We do not know at this stage-threatening noises keep coming from across the aisle about opposition or amendment to the various elements of the tax reform package which will provide the revenue to provide the tax cuts. Let it be known that, if the taxation package is sabotaged by the Opposition in the Senate to the point where it is impossible to deliver the income tax cuts which the Government has promised, the responsibility for that will rest fairly and squarely with members of the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia and the Australian Democrats.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of Press reports that the United Nations is facing a severe financial crisis and that this is likely to affect its operation substantially? Can the Minister advise the extent of the financial crisis presently faced by the United Nations? In the face of this crisis, will the Government reaffirm its commitment to the maintenance of the United Nations and to its many worthwhile programs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 April-that is, Monday of this week-the United Nations General Assembly resumed its 1985 session for one week at the request of the Secretary-General to consider the very real financial crisis that is facing the United Nations. The crisis has arisen after many years in which a growing number of member states of the United Nations have failed to pay in full their assessed contributions to the regular budget. Their arrears totalled $US242m at the end of 1985 and fully committed the financial reserves of the organisation. Further shortfalls in payments of assessed contributions in 1986 will place the United Nations in danger of not being able to carry out its approved work program or meet its financial obligations. At 31 March this year only 16 states, of which Australia was one, had paid their contributions for 1986 and owed no debt. Separately, arrears in payments for the United Nations peace-keeping operations totalled some $US275m.

ANSWER.PARA: The Secretary-General described the financial crisis facing the organisation as a threat to the viability of the United Nations and its present and future effectiveness. He noted that restoration of the financial stability of the United Nations in the longer term required member states to address fundamental issues related to the budgetary process. The Secretary-General has proposed a package of short term cost saving measures, likely to save $US76m in 1986, and indications from New York are that that package will be accepted today when the resumed session is due to conclude.

As to Australia's attitude, this country, as a committed supporter of the United Nations and a major contributor to the budget-its contribution this year being $US16m-is actively involved in the resumed session. Australia is not, however, uncritical of the United Nations, its effectiveness, and its budgetary and administrative performance. We believe that a process of review and reform is urgently required and have made plain our views in this regard. Addressing the General Assembly on 29 April, the Australian permanent representative to the United Nations made the following points: That Australia has a strong and steadfast commitment to the United Nations and the multilateral system; that Australia wants the United Nations to emerge stronger and more effective from the current crisis; that withholding of payment of assessed contributions by member states is contrary to obligations under the United Nations charter; that late payments of assessed contributions contribute significantly to the financial instability of the United Nations; that important reforms are required to restore the financial stability and political credibility of the United Nations; and that the Secretary-General has not made sufficient effort to address some of the fundamental issues which underlie the financial crisis.
I conclude by quoting Mr Woolcott's final remarks in this respect when he said:

The resumed session provides an opportunity to begin the process of rebuilding consensus on the major budgetary issues. We need to consider what we most want the Organisation to do and how best to fund this. Australia is prepared to pull its weight and to play a positive role in this process.

The United Nations is too important to us all, as the only truly international institution we have, to be allowed to wither away, or become enfeebled because of our inability to meet the challenge posed by the present financial crisis. If we fail to meet this challenge we shall all lose.

I hope that the Opposition will take some appropriate opportunity to endorse those sentiments. There has been a regrettable absence of strong bipartisan support in recent times for the United Nations and its agencies. I think at a time like this it is appropriate that we act unanimously as a nation to support the kinds of views that are there set out.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. In the recent rural economic package reference was made to the creation of a new figure for taxation purposes for the value ascribed to natural increases in the stock of stud breeders. Precisely how will this new figure be determined?

—I believe that this is a Treasury question rather than a primary industry question. I will answer what I believe to be the case, but I cannot guarantee the accuracy. I will answer the question with the caveat `subject to confirmation by the Treasurer or perhaps further details by the Treasurer'. Firstly, for those who do not know it, it is customary for livestock to have imputed to it a taxation value at the end of each financial year-a value for tax purposes as a sort of trading stock valuation. There are arbitrarily determined figures for various types of livestock-it is something like $1 for sheep, $5 for a cow and perhaps something like $10 for a horse.
—How much for a Ronnie Boswell?

—How much for a goat? I do not know. The proposition, as I understand it, is that that figure will have to be at least equal to the fee paid for the stud stock service or, in the case of, say, a racehorse or a sheep, the tax value put on the stock at the end of the year must be at least equal to the price paid for the ram which sired the sheep.
—Will you repeat the last sentence please?

—The value placed on each lamb at 30 June would have to be at least equal to the price paid for the ram which sired the lambs. That is subject to confirmation, but I think it is basically the change which is proposed.

—I ask a supplementary question. In a stud herd where one is breeding from a line and has not purchased the sire or the dam and it is not customary to charge a service fee for the stallion or the bull, how would this figure be arrived at?
—My understanding is that under those circumstances it would not apply.

—Has the Minister for Veterans' Affairs been made aware of a rumour circulating at least in the veteran community that totally and permanently incapacitated pensioners have been called in by the Department of Veterans' Affairs for medical reviews for the purpose of assessing continuing eligibility to receive a totally and permanently incapacitated pension? Can the Minister advise whether these medical reviews are actually taking place or whether there is any basis for that rumour?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is absolutely no truth in the rumours that have been circulating in one or two States suggesting that there is to be some change in the criteria relating to the granting or otherwise of the totally and permanently incapacitated pension. I have no idea who is responsible for such an ill-founded contention, nor do I understand the motivation of those using such scaremongering tactics. Unfortunately, in the political process political point scoring takes place in the Parliament from time to time and all sorts of statements are made, but some people then want to extend that point scoring to give credence to statements and rumours which really create concern amongst the very group in the Australian community that ought to be protected from such scaremongering.

ANSWER.PARA: The present TPI criteria have been operating since 6 June 1985 following the May economic statement. At that time the Acting Minister for Veterans' Affairs in the debate on the second reading to the then Veterans' Entitlements Bill gave assurances that no presently entitled veteran receiving a disability pension or war widow would be affected by any changes in the Veterans' Entitlements Bill. I emphasised that again in my recent second reading speech but despite the assurances that the Government and my representative in the House of Representatives have given these rumours continue to gain some credence. Under the Veterans' Entitlements Bill there is a specific legislative provision to ensure that a veteran is not disadvantaged by the application of the provisions of the Veterans' Entitlements Bill in respect of a pension that was granted before the Veterans' Entitlements Act came into operation. One can only say that there is absolutely no truth that any person will be affected by the recent legislation. I deprecate any attempts that are made by rumour mongers to create confusion and concern in the ranks of veterans.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Resources and Energy confirm that the compensation to be paid under the Oil Companies (Stock Loss Reimbursement) Bill is intended to minimise stock losses caused by government action? Is it correct that there is no plan to reimburse retailers in any way for their losses caused by the Government's action? As the Government has declared that the retailers' potential for stock losses is a great deal less than for refiners, are we to understand that the Government is concerned only with the problems of big business?

—The question is based on a false premise; that is to say, that retailers have suffered significant stock losses as a result of the changing and rapidly declining import parity price of oil. That is simply not the case. They have a much faster throughput of refined product in the service stations than is the case with refineries, where the time taken for crude oil to come into one end and go out the other end is something like two months and where revaluations of the amount of stock involved do have massive financial implications. For retailers, depending on the volumes and turnover of their sales and so on, the periods are much less than that. It is the case that price adjustments are usually made by arrangement between the refiners and the retailers in such a way as to ensure that no loss at all is incurred by the retailer. That is certainly my understanding. It is a bit more complex than that to spell it out. I will provide a more detailed answer if it seems to me to be appropriate to do so when I have had a further look at that question. But it is my understanding that nobody has suffered any significant losses at the retail level and, as such, the question of compensation does not arise.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Finance been drawn to an article in this morning's Business Review Weekly detailing the Northern Territory Government's bankrolling of Mr Jay Pendarvis's Mudginberri abattoir in the Northern Territory? If so, can the Minister comment on the contents of that article?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article referred to published in today's Business Review Weekly. The information in it is, I might observe, entirely consistent with information which came my way some time ago, but not from the Business Review Weekly. Basically what it says is that last year Mr Pendarvis, the abattoir's proprietor, was advanced all but $8,000 of a $1m item which appeared in the Northern Territory Budget. It came through the Minister for Primary Production, Mr Hatton.

ANSWER.PARA: The authority is called the Agricultural Development and Marketing Authority and its budget is supposed to provide incentives for growers and farmers to market their produce with advance payments, but, as I said, all but $8,000 of the $1m was advanced to Mr Pendarvis. When the Authority ran out of funds, the Northern Territory Government contacted Westpac to inquire whether the bank would advance $2m to Pendarvis against a government guarantee. The bank agreed and a memorandum was signed by Mr Hatton and Mudginberri abattoirs which required Mudginberri to pursue damages claims against the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union. Mr Tuxworth signed the government guarantee to Westpac on the $2m advance from Westpac. Eight weeks later the Northern Territory Government announced that its $1.3 billion account would transfer from the Reserve Bank to Westpac, so it looks as if there was a bit of a trade-off there as well. As well as the trade-offs between the territorial government and Mr Pendarvis there was another trade-off-or a sleazy, under the table deal, if you like-between the Government and Westpac. The editor of Business Review Weekly, Mr Simpson, said on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation this morning:
We think there are a number of very important questions which need answering.
He further said:
. . . there should be some form of judicial inquiry into the whole Mudginberri situation.

Some people would probably add to that that there should be a much wider ranging judicial inquiry into administration by the Northern Territory Government in general. Finally, I think it is worth noting that Mr Howard said that he would like to see a thousand Mudginberris. If that were to happen, it would add between $1 billion and $3 billion to the $1.5 billion in extra expenditure which Mr Howard has already promised in his irresponsible spending spree.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to Senator Grimes in the absence of the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to comments made by the Prime Minister in his speech at the Australian Mining Industry Council dinner last night in which he claimed that inflation was likely to decline in the near future partly because of what he called the circuit breaker of the expected delay in the payment of the current wage case. I ask the Minister: Is this not an admission by the Prime Minister that wage indexation is the major direct cause of an inflation rate which has never before compared so badly with our trading partners as it does today. Is it not also an admission of the folly of the Australian Labor Party and Australian Council of Trade Unions accord and the current ACTU claim for a 3 per cent productivity rise which everyone knows Australia cannot afford?
—Unlike Senator Parer, I have yet to read the Prime Minister's speech.
—Shame!

—I am a little like Senator Withers. I do not read everything that comes in. Senator Withers says he does not read the newspapers, but he seems to know a fair bit about it. I am always surprised when Senator Parer and others in this place get up and attack the accord. The accord has been the linchpin of the Government's economic policy in the last three years, and I point out to Senator Parer that it has been a very successful economic policy. From the look of the polls in the Australian this week and the Bulletin last week, the majority of the Australian people agree with that. The accord has meant that we have changed the economy from the situation that existed before we got in, where 300,000 people had just been added to the unemployment list, where inflation was at a record level, where there was a general feeling of despair in the community, and where the business community would not invest. That economic policy, of which I say the accord is the linchpin, has resulted in wages holding at a much better level than the previous Government was capable of when we had that extraordinary expansion of wages in the early 1980s, and it continues to be successful. It is only people like Senator Parer who take the isolated view that when in Opposition one knocks everything the Government does, regardless of what the Government does. That sort of approach is one of the reasons why I recommend to him that he look at the polls in the Australian last week and the Bulletin the week before and think about why his Party is in the situation it is at the moment.

—I have a supplementary question. I refer the Minister to the remarks by the Prime Minister that inflation is likely to climb because the delay in the payment of the wage case is the circuit breaker. Is this not an admission that wage indexation is a direct cause of the inflation rate?

—No, I do not think it is anything of the sort. I am sure the Prime Minister did not say that that was the only reason that inflation would come down. I will read the Prime Minister's speech and if I have been unkind to Senator Parer I will come back and say so.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment. Has the Kurnell Peninsula on Botany Bay been zoned as a section 4 (c) (4) area under the New South Wales Planning and Environment Act? Would this permit companies like Bayer Australia Ltd and the Australian Gas Light Company, both of which have applications before the New South Wales Minister for Planning and Environment, to operate in this area? Could such operations be classified as noxious, toxic or hazardous under the terms of the Act? Is Australia a signatory to the 1971 Ramsar Convention on the protection of wetlands and is the Towra Point site on the Kurnell Peninsula such an area? How does this rezoning square with our obligations under the Convention?

—In June 1975 the Commonwealth Government purchased 281.8 hectares of freehold land at Towra Point at a cost of $3.85m for nature conservation purposes. The land was later transferred to New South Wales as part of a Commonwealth-State land exchange agreement on the understanding that it would be dedicated as a nature reserve under the New South Wales legislation. Towra Point Nature Reserve has been accepted as a wetland of international importance under the Ramsar Convention. Australia is a party to that Convention. The area is also a significant habitat for migratory wading birds covered by the Japan-Australia migratory birds agreement. The Commonwealth has retained an interest in the area through participation of the National Parks and Wildlife Service on an advisory committee which advises on management of the Towra Point Nature Reserve. The Director of ANPWS recently wrote to the Director of the New South Wales National Parks and Wildlife Service nominating a representative on the new advisory committee that will cover all of the reserves in Botany Bay. —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance and follows his reply earlier in question time on the current account deficit as a proportion of gross domestic product and the claim he made today, which he has made before in the Senate, that it would never reach the level of 1981-82. —I direct my question to the Minister for Resources and Energy. The Minister would be aware of the widespread complaints about the use of unleaded petrol in cars-the offensive smell and the effect on drivers' health, especially those who spend a high proportion of their day on the road. Can the Minister provide an up to date report on this matter? What can be done about it and what advice does he give to those who have to drive cars that run on ULP?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that in recent weeks there have been a number of complaints by Commonwealth car drivers, their passengers and the Automobile Association of Australia about hydrogen sulphide odours, or rotten egg gas, arising in cars running on unleaded petrol. The precise cause of the reported smell problem is not known at this stage. However, the New South Wales Pollution Control Commission has initiated laboratory investigations and environmental authorities have asked for an early report on the matter from the oil and motor industries.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment, which I am pleased to say has the co-ordinating responsibility for this matter rather than my Department-I am the Minister for petrol prices, not the Minister for petrol pongs-is consulting with other departments to review the situation. I can say further that the problem does not appear to be caused directly by the fuel and is confined to vehicles with catalytic converter pollution controls. Standards for both leaded and unleaded grades of petrol have been published, I am told, by the Standards Association of Australia. These standards are in line with the best overseas refining practice and were determined after full consultation involving the oil and motor industries. So far, at least, there has been no suggestion that the quality of ULP supplied to the Australian market does not comply with the standard. The effect on odour of vehicle type, state of engine, tune, and engine and system design is still under investigation. I am afraid that while all that is happening I am unable to add any further advice as to how drivers should cope with potential health problems arising out of this or, for that matter, the psychological pressure that I expect they are under from new passengers getting into their cars and looking so often sideways at them.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs been drawn to an article in yesterday's edition of the Brisbane Courier-Mail which claimed that efforts are under way to establish sanctuaries in Queensland to harbour illegal immigrants in so-called safe houses throughout the State? Does the article quote an anonymous Brisbane solicitor as saying that illegal immigrants offered sanctuary would be those whom organisers consider to have been disadvantaged by tough immigration laws, with those seeking to escape political persecution in their own countries at the top of the list? As the so-called Queensland Movement is said to be linked with a Melbourne-based organisation comprising mainly church and social workers, I ask: What action can the Australian Government take to stamp out this threat to its orderly immigration laws and procedures?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been a number of recent Press reports, including the one referred to by Senator Jones in the Courier-Mail quoting an anonymous solicitor who claimed that an Australian group is being formed to give sanctuary to illegal immigrants in Australia, especially those `fleeing political persecution in their home countries'. Australia has a well-established and long-established and respected procedure for handling claims by people who arrive in Australia seeking refugee status. It is in the individual's interests to approach the appropriate authorities with any claims that he or she may have. I believe that it is in the interest of people such as members of Parliament, who sometimes get approached in this regard, to approach the Government.

ANSWER.PARA: All claims are examined thoroughly and no one is deported while a claim is being processed. Applications are examined by the Determination of Refugee Status Committee. It is not a decision-making body, but it makes recommendations to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. It is government policy not to discuss individual cases. This policy was designed many years ago to protect the individuals who are making claims. Illegal immigrants without refugee claims should be dealt with in accordance with the current legislative and policy provisions relevant to their situation, and the Australian Government simply cannot, as any previous government could not, condone queue-jumping of this type. People who knowingly break the law or encourage others to do so expose themselves to penalties under the Migration Act.

It is to be noted that the Courier-Mail indicated that the Reverend Hall-Matthews, the Anglican Bishop of Carpentaria, had said that there was no need for anyone in Australia to panic about illegal immigrants; he warned that the sanctuary movement could jeopardise the future of West Irian refugees in the Torres Strait islands; and that he said that he considered that the Government had handled cases in a humanitarian way. Those people who might be thinking of establishing such illegal procedures would be well advised to take the advice of the Reverend Hall-Matthews and deal with this matter in a legal and sensible way.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in Question Time today Senator Newman asked me a question about possible compensation for retailers for stock losses following reductions in oil prices. I have some further information which I think is appropriate to put on record. The first point I make in confirmation of what I said earlier on is that, whereas refiners' stocks are normally held for 50 to 60 days, city retailers' stock levels would last for only three to seven days, and in country areas about nine to 10 days. So the retailers' exposure to inventory losses is therefore much less than is the case for refiners.

ANSWER.PARA: Some other points could be added. Retailers have had the option of running stock down in anticipation of the price fall each time that has occurred, not least because of the gap of a fortnight or so between the announcement of a reduction in import parity prices and the follow-on wholesale price reduction by the Prices Surveillance Authority. The extent that retailers could deplete their stock is dependent on their commercial judgments about the timing of deliveries of lower-priced products and the consequences of running out of supplies entirely. Their position, in this respect, is in marked contrast with that of the refiners, which, if they are to comply with the crude oil allocation scheme, are simply not free to exercise their commercial judgment about taking deliveries.

The final point that I make is that petrol retailers, unlike refiner wholesalers, are not bound by the decisions of the Prices Surveillance Authority, which sets the maximum wholesale price of petroleum. So, subject, of course, to local competitive pressures, retailers are able to dispose of old stock at the retail price they consider appropriate, given market forces prevailing at the time. I do not doubt that there may have been some experience of small inventory losses around the place, but I reiterate the point I made earlier that those losses are really quite negligible and within the scope of ordinary criteria of commercial risk-quite unlike the situation confronting the refiners, which is the subject of the present legislation.
