SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the lunch break I listed six specific concerns that I have about the operation of the community employment program. I asked the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) to give urgent consideration to these concerns and criticisms. The Minister seems to have become increasingly sensitive to criticism about the CEP and about individual CEP projects. I am amazed and very disturbed to learn that in recent days Mr Willis has directed that any information on CEP projects must be channelled through his office. Why has he issued this directive? What does he think might be disclosed? This is an extraordinary decision which raises the suspicions of honourable senators on this side of the chamber, and many in the outside community, about the operation and administration of the scheme.
—What about making us pay to get information under the Freedom of Information Act?

—That is right. We have to pay to get information which should be readily available publicly to any member of the community. The Minister should think again about this misguided direction. He should not lightly dismiss the criticisms which have been raised about the community employment program, not just by politicians but also by many people in the community. I am sorry to say that there is a growing distrust of the CEP in the electorate and that is not good for the scheme or, more importantly, for its intended beneficiaries.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make some comments about the design of the program. The community employment program appears to have developed a momentum of its own. It appears to be unrelated to the Government's youth traineeship scheme and, if there is a lack of relationship there, this could lead to waste and duplication in administration. The Kirby Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs brought down a report which led to the development of the traineeship scheme, but it specifically excluded from its study any research on the CEP. Hence the CEP does not appear to be integrated into the Hawke Government's other job schemes. The Government must tell the people of Australia how these two seemingly independent schemes will be made to work side by side. For example, are the on-the-job training programs of the CEP now redundant? Will CEP project workers be eligible for youth traineeships? I understand that all these questions are still up in the air. Certainly a large number of people in the community do not know the answers.
In June last year Anthony King, of the social policy research unit of the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research, made this claim:
Measured against the program principles recommended by the Kirby report, the CEP does not stand up well.
He also said that the CEP was:
. . . not fully effective in assisting the most disadvantaged unemployed.

Bishop Peter Hollingworth, who has taken a great and compassionate concern and interest in the problems of the long term unemployed, in his book Australians in Poverty, reinforces this view by pointing out the substantial reasons for long term unemployment. According to Bishop Hollingworth, 74 per cent of the long term unemployed in Australia are unemployed because of special disabilities. It is cruel to portray the CEP as being able to assist these unemployed people, especially when one considers the nature of some CEP projects-building swimming pools, assisting in laboratories, surveys, market research and the like. Anthony King also said in his 1985 study:

The CEP focuses on the needs of project sponsors, rather than prospective individual participants, with project design and approval occurring in advance of recruitment from the eligible unemployed. In only a few cases under the job creation schemes have projects been designed with close consideration of the needs of individuals.

This analysis points to an urgent need to integrate the more legitimate aspects of the CEP into the traineeship scheme and other related schemes. Quite frankly, the CEP appears to be a juggernaut with its own mindless self-serving momentum and the result is a chaotic waste of taxpayers' funds in many instances.

The figures prove that the CEP is making little impact on the long term unemployed and pockets of unemployment are as entrenched as ever. I mentioned that before lunch. The recent report by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, entitled `CEP-the second year', merely crunches numbers to show how certain targets are met. There is no real attempt to look behind the screen and show us what is really going on. It seems that we are forced to turn to magazines such as the Bulletin and private research to gain a real feel for the way in which the program is going off the rails. About 18,500 projects have been approved or will be approved in the first 30 months of the CEP. That involves $1.3 billion. This is a massive amount of money and it raises the question of whether the projects are adequately monitored. My office has been informed that it is not unusual for a CEP project officer to have 70 schemes to supervise at the one time. This may well be the reason for the widespread problems that are being reported because obviously it is impossible for any person to administer 70 projects efficiently in that way.

As a result of constituent concern my office studied in detail the largest CEP project in Victoria-the Footscray Swim Centre project-and found that contrary to the explicit guidelines set out in the document `CEP-the second year' there were many abuses. For example, the official sponsor was apparently not capable of managing the approved project but the guidelines say that official sponsors must be capable. The sponsor had not spent three quarters of its proposed contribution, despite raising a public loan for the project. The project had extended over 32 months, well beyond the maximum period of 12 months, and is still very far from completed. I am sorry, I think that that figure of 32 months is a mistake; I think the timescale is more like 18 to 20 months. Failure to meet the general CEP requirements could result in suspension or termination of the grant for the Footscray project, yet the Minister seems little concerned to call the sponsor to account. That may be because this project is in his own electorate and it may be because the apparent sponsor is a Labor controlled council. How often have the abuses been detailed and acted upon in other projects? The Minister should make it an urgent priority to ensure an open and public audit of the larger CEP projects.

At the heart of the CEP's problems is the Government's frantic desire to find jobs to sponsor. It seems that any job would appear suitable. Local councils and State governments are using CEP funds as a source of revenue for projects that should be carried out in the normal course of their own duties. CEP funds are being used to underwrite their own budgets and are a way of avoiding a more restrained approach to expenditure. On top of that, private organisations have made a profession of approaching councils with proposals for certain projects, and I think that Senator Jessop will probably give some example of that. It is doubtful whether many of these projects are of benefit to the community. The Minister should be concerned about this developing practice of companies spruiking for business. Additionally, funds are being directed towards subsidising certain lifestyles, often with political overtones, and many of these have been financially disastrous. Many have also been in areas that are more the normal requirement of State government financing. In my own area of Victoria-in Mr Willis's electorate-one of the local newspapers, the Mail, recently claimed that $8m given under the CEP for beautification along rivers and creeks in the area was `a flop, and a fiasco'. The paper blamed bureaucratic bungling. Fences built have since fallen down and weeds have overgrown the areas because of a lack of ongoing maintenance. In addition to this $8m, there is the cost of the Footscray swimming pool project that I have mentioned, bringing the total to about $10m with virtually no community benefit at this stage. Funds have been handed over to fringe political groups with little or no job-making potential.

In conclusion, I repeat my initial comments in this debate that the Opposition does not oppose the extension for three years of the CEP scheme as proposed in this Bill. However, I and other Opposition speakers both in the Senate and in the House of Representatives have raised serious issues of concern in the interests of the supposed beneficiaries of the CEP scheme, namely, the long term unemployed. They are genuine complaints, criticisms and concerns. I believe that the Government will be sadly failing in its duty if it does not pursue these issues as a matter of urgency.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join this debate in order to highlight some of my concerns about the community employment program as we know it today. This, I think is the third generation employment scheme that Australia has been subjected to. The first was the regional employment development scheme, which was introduced during the Whitlam years, at a time when the number of unemployed youth in particular mushroomed, to a very large extent due to the Whitlam excesses and maladministration of that time. Another scheme was known as the SUR scheme-the special unemployment relief scheme-the object of which was to provide temporary employment relief. Now we are dealing with the community employment program.

SPEECH.PARA: Any government and the people of Australia believe that unemployment is a scourge on our community, and successive governments have done their best to introduce schemes that provide some opportunity for the unemployed to obtain employment, even if it is on a temporary scale, with the hope that this could lead to more permanent occupation. Job opportunities will not be created until the Government understands that the high cost of socialist governments are preventing any real recovery in the private sector. That, of course, is where the job opportunities should be created. At the same time, intolerable pressures are growing within the community for the unemployed to be made to work for the dole. The CEP scheme is a pilot scheme for any national work-for-dole scheme. The Government will eventually have to implement something a little more permanent if unemployment is to be overcome under its administration. These pressures are such that many young people have come to me in recent times and suggested that they would be interested even in national service as a means of occupying themselves, gaining better work experience and perhaps learning a trade. Those benefits, of course, are available through the armed forces, but that is another matter. However, this highlights the concern that exists in the community with respect to this problem.

In the light of what I have said, let us examine the CEP as a pilot scheme. The first deduction must be that the scheme is inefficient and fails either to cure unemployment or to train the unemployed in sound work practices. Of course, the nature of the scheme is such that those who have been unemployed for the longest period are employed in the first stages. Quite frequently, unfortunately, these people are in the unemployeable category and do not last for very long on these projects. As a result, we find that we are not getting the full value that we would hope for for the work input. Councils and others have told me that it takes several months before they can get a stable, reasonably efficient work force under this system. So there are problems that we have to expect in a scheme of this nature.

I notice that local government is involved in a lot of these projects. I am concerned that much of the work is done at this level. It is not that I am suggesting that all councils cannot cope with it, but some find difficulty in doing so. They do not have the technical know-how and the resources to exercise effective financial control in order to guarantee the successful completion of such projects. I am not saying that that applies to every council, because some of them can cope and do it quite well. This was highlighted by Senator Vanstone this morning when she referred to representations that have been made to her from the Hawker District Council indicating that it is not interested in the CEP scheme for the reasons that I have suggested.

Senator Maguire criticised me for raising questions related to the operation of Trojan Owen and Associates Pty Ltd. That matter arose because of comments made to me following Senator Short's raising of the matter-he has repeated this today-of the Footscray Swim Centre. I asked a question whether it is a fact that Trojan Owen and Associates has in some instances obtained preferential and privileged information from Federal and/or State departments involved in the CEP about intending projects of some potential sponsor organisations. I went on to ask:
Has it been the first and sometimes only company to approach such sponsor organisations offering its services before the project has even been approved?

I did that in good faith because I wanted to clear this matter up. I have had complaints about this matter levelled at me through my office, and I felt it was fair enough for me to ask the Government to give me information on that matter. Senator Walsh in reply said:

I am sure Senator Jessop will be surprised to know that I cannot remember the answers to all those questions. In fact, I cannot remember all the questions. Answers should be obtainable for most of them, I think, and I will try to get them.

That was on 14 March. Now we are into May and I still have not had any clarification on the points that I raised. We are all familiar with the Footscray Swim Centre to which Senator Short has referred. In South Australia we are all familiar with the surfacing at a cost of just over $5m of two kilometres of road through the Unley district not far from where I live. I believe that this is the tip of the iceberg. The expenditure of $5m for two kilometres of road seems to me to be extraordinary. I believe that in excess of 150 people were employed on that project, and I heard that at least one of them has obtained full time employment as a result of it.

I want to give one or two examples. The first concerns the Adelaide Central Mission. This mission obtained $541,000 to modify the mission building. The mission was required to provide a further $433,000, making a total of $974,000. The first floor of the mission now looks like a bomb site. The money has run out and there is no more money available to complete the project. A further $140,000 is needed to complete the project and the mission, being the sponsor, will have to find that money. The mission did not have the professional experience to plan or supervise that project or another one in which it was involved at Kuitpo Colony, which is managed by the Mission. Therefore it turned to a firm which came into business to become involved with the regional employment development scheme initially, and now the community employment program scheme. Other firms are in the same business, but the Central Mission chose to employ Trojan Owen and Associates Pty Ltd for a fee of approximately $172,000 for the two projects.

Other projects with which Trojan Owen has been associated and for which fees have been paid are at the Linear Reserve at Taperoo Beach and the redevelopment of the war memorial at a total cost of $750,000, of which the CEP fund contribution was $500,000 and the fee to Trojan Owen was about $85,000; Victor Harbor District Council indoor recreation centre; Hindmarsh River development; restoration work at Waipinga; and restoration work on the Bluff. The total cost of those projects is $2.13m, with the CEP fund contribution being over $1m and fees to the supervising company of $222,000. It is fair to say that with respect to those projects the Town Clerk of Victor Harbor stated that this particular firm is the best operator of CEP projects in his experience and it was singularly successful at Victor Harbor.

The Noarlunga City Council was involved as sponsors in the Onkaparinga Estuary conservation and development project stage 1 at a total cost of $1.2m, with a CEP contribution of $775,000 and between 8 and 10 per cent of the total cost, or $110,000, going to the supervising company. The Burnside City Council was involved in the redevelopment of the Chelsea Theatre indoor sporting complex-a project to which Senator Maguire referred-at a cost of $1.8m, with a CEP contribution of $1.2m and fees of about 8 per cent, or $138,000, going to the supervising contractor. I have seen the Chelsea Theatre and the company did an excellent job there. It refurbished the theatre and retained the character of the original building, which is quite a commendable achievement. However, that project went over budget. Such cost is usually expected to be found by the sponsor, in this case the Burnside City Council. I understand that Senator Maguire is a ratepayer of that Council. It is interesting to note that one CEP worker on the Chelsea Theatre project is still on workmen's compensation two years after the completion of the project.

Another CEP project is the Memorial Drive Tennis Club public administration building and club facilities, at a total cost of $500,000, with a CEP contribution of $340,000 and a fee to Trojan Owen of $45,000, which is roughly 8 to 10 per cent. It took a long time for this project to get under way. No skilled advice was available, according to the reports I have received from the Commonwealth Employment Service, and the job was completed for $200,000 over budget. I understand that the supervising company had an employee visit the site occasionally, the site foreman having been employed by the company through the CES. The Noarlunga City Council Onkaparinga Estuary conservation and development stage 2 project cost is $1.6m. That project is awaiting CEP funding, but the fee to Trojan Owen is to be about 10 per cent or $160,000. The Adelaide City Council scheme for the River Torrens enhancement has a total cost of $750,000. I am not sure what the CEP contribution will be, but the fee charged by Trojan Owen will be 8 to 10 per cent or $60,000. This project has been postponed, I understand, because of other work on the site. From these jobs alone Trojan Owen has received something of the order of $820,000.

The firm has been doing this sort of work since about 1978. I have been told that Mr Eric Trojan left the firm in 1979, but Mr Owen has kept the company name. Mr Don Owen is known in Adelaide as an ideas man, in that he is very good at creating projects and doing all the paper work necessary for an application to be submitted under the CEP. He has done some very valuable work in that respect. However, I have been given to understand that once a project has approval and has started only one or two employees of the company supervising the project monitor the project, and this is carried out on a part time basis while other projects are being initiated. I understand also from what I have been told that the firm normally carries out more than one project at a time, which puts added strain on its ability to supervise these projects.

Another example I would like to give deals with a yabbie farm that has been started for the Gerard Reserve Aboriginal community in the Riverland. The Gerard Reserve community was approached by Mr Owen of Trojan Owen and Associates with a proposal to build this yabbie farm if the community could get CEP funds. The proposal was that Trojan Owen was to do all the work on the project. With the support of the Aboriginal Development Commission, the community succeeded in getting approval from the CEP secretariat in Adelaide and the relevant State and Federal departments. Prior to getting approval, Trojan Owen and the Aboriginal Development Commission wrote to the State Department of Fisheries outlining the proposal and asking for its technical comment on it. The Department of Fisheries said that it looked like a good project but pointed to a need for a lot of preparatory work and feasibility studies to be carried out before it went ahead and got approval. That was in June 1983. The next that the Department of Fisheries heard of the project was when the announcement was made in a newspaper in September 1983 that the project had the approval for funding and that it would proceed under the responsibility of the Department of Fisheries. That was news to the Department, because it had not been asked to do a feasibility study or to contribute anything further since June 1983.

The initial CEP funding was $434,000 and the Aboriginal Development Commission contributed a total of $104,000, consisting of half loan and half grant. The low interest loan was to be paid back once the yabbie farm started to make revenue. These funds were given to the Gerard Reserve Council and it employed Trojan Owen to manage the project. Since the Department of Fisheries was publicly forced to shoulder some of the responsibility for the project, even though at that stage it had had no input, it pushed for the establishment of a review group to monitor the progress of the project. Mr Don Owen of Trojan Owen was made chairman of this review group. The Department of Fisheries was very concerned that it could not get this review group to hold enough meetings. From September 1983 to January 1985, when the review group folded, it met on only three occasions.

Once approval for the project was given, money had to be spent by certain dates to fulfil the employment obligations under the CEP guidelines. This meant that Trojan Owen was virtually designing the project as it went along. According to the Department of Fisheries, no in-depth feasibility study had been carried out. Engineering problems were encountered on the project and one of the yabbie hatcheries fell down during construction. Apparently it was lucky that no one was injured as a result. It is not surprising that the project fell behind schedule and eventually ran out of money. The Aboriginal Development Commission told the project sponsors and the various Government departments that it could not afford to grant any more money for further construction costs. The State Department of Labour and the Commonwealth Department of Employment and Industrial relations, which run the CEP, decided to top-up the $434,000 already given to the project. Apparently, the total funds designated for this as yet uncompleted project are approaching $700,000.

The future of the project currently is under review and Trojan Owen has not played any further part in it since work has come to a halt. The remaining funds have been held back until this review has been completed. The Aboriginal Development Commission employed an independent engineering firm to find out how much more money would be needed to complete this project. The State Department of Labour and the Commonwealth Department of Employment and Industrial Relations also asked the Commonwealth Department of Housing and Construction to undertake a review of the project. It is now at the stage where someone has to make a decision as to whether more money should be granted to complete the project or whether they should cut their losses and give up the project altogether. No doubt the Gerard Reserve Aboriginal community is not too impressed with how it has all turned out. The Department of Fisheries does not want any part of this disaster since it was never formally or actively involved in the project, regardless of what the newspaper announcement to which I referred earlier said. The CEP secretariat has been asking Trojan Owen for financial and other information relating to the project because the Gerard Reserve Council accepted directions from the project managers, Trojan Owen, once funds were approved.

Apparently, engineers from Canberra have visited the site and suggested that a few hundred thousand dollars would be needed to complete stage I and to get it operating. Mr Owen was responsible for employing a civil engineer to do the original design work and costings. At the moment the Gerard Reserve Council is left with six or seven big holes in the ground and one or two sheds. At the time of this project Trojan Owen apparently had several other projects under its supervision.

Although I have mentioned this firm, Trojan Owen, because it has had some publicity as a result of Senator Short's interest, other management consultants are available in South Australia. Apparently one in particular has a special relationship with some of the staff of the CEP secretariat. In South Australia one such firm specialising in education facilities has been created, I understand with some contact with the State Department of Education. That Department laid down procedures whereby each project was to obtain technical approval from the construction authority, the State Department of Housing and Construction, and the Education Department. In at least two cases both the Education Department and the construction authority were bypassed and the CEP secretariat funded the project. I am told that both projects are technically and financially in a mess. It is no wonder that we are concerned about the way this scheme is being carried out.

I will cite one more example of matters that are giving me concern. Under Mr Uren's Department of Local Government and Administrative Services, I understand that the Torrens River banks are being cleaned up as part of the natural areas enhancement scheme. The State Insurance Office was asked to provide workmen's compensation cover and demanded 43 per cent of the labour costs as a premium because of the lack of compensation history of projects undertaken by that Department. That premium of 43 per cent of labour costs is horrendous. It must be asked why Mr Uren's Department has to run this scheme. The insurance for the building trades in South Australia, for example, in 1982-83 was about 3.4 per cent of labour costs, and for the metal trades was about 4 per cent. The average for CEP projects was 14 per cent during that year, which is high enough. I have talked about local government before and, generally speaking, local government does not want to be involved with workers compensation because of its experience up to now. If local government and project managers are not properly supervising CEP jobs then bad work practices are likely to occur and, certainly, compensation claims greater than normally must be expected. The pattern in respect of workers compensation claims is as follows: When the job begins it takes a little while for those who must be offered the work under the rules to start the job. As I have stated before, sometimes they fall by the wayside. The work force then settles down, but when completion of the job is in sight CEP employees sometimes drop out, claiming injury. That has happened in many instances. I referred to the case of the CEP worker involved with the Chelsea Theatre who was still receiving workers compensation after two years.

I do not believe that the community employment program is properly administered because it is not properly structured, the correct controls are lacking and, I am told, there are problems that ought to be looked at and overcome. We in the Opposition support the community employment program, but we must exert every effort to ensure that the scheme is more effective and more economic. I am sure that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) would agree that the points I have raised are important. If we are wasting money, as I have suggested, and sponsors are required to find further finance because projects are going over the estimated cost, I think that inhibits the scheme and prevents its becoming successful. I am raising these matters in a very constructive sense and I hope that we will be able to get the Government to find some answers to the questions that were posed earlier by Senator Short and Senator Michael Baume, and to the points raised by me.

Senator Short pointed out that his staff are having difficulty in getting any information either from the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, at regional or head offices, or from the CEP secretariat. Each inquiry is now referred to the Minister's office, who when approached states that there are three ways of obtaining information. The first is to write a letter requesting information. The second is to ask a question in the Senate. The third is to seek information through the Freedom of Information Act. I have sought the information I want through the Senate and I have asked a question of Senator Walsh. Six weeks later, I am still waiting for an answer. I now ask the Minister whether he will undertake to ensure that explicit answers are provided to the questions I have raised. In mentioning Trojan Owen in particular, I do not want to suggest that in every instance that company is not properly supervising those projects; it has been quite successful in regard to a number of them. However, I am afraid that in others there are reports to my office from various responsible sponsors that the supervision has not always been what it should be. I suggest that that might apply to other companies as well. I think the Department ought to provide a little more technical advice to the sponsors concerned and it ought to provide some assistance in respect of financial supervision of these various projects.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Community Employment Amendment Bill essentially extends the program that has existed for some time through to 1989. Regrettably, this program will be needed as part of the general employment and welfare schemes until that time. The unemployment rate is hovering at about 8 per cent. According to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) this is unlikely to decline in the near future. Indeed, it is the Government's policy to restrict economic growth to about 3 per cent, which makes any decline in unemployment virtually impossible. Eight per cent unemployment represents almost 600,000 people. Those people, on December 1985 figures, have 217,000 dependent children. If one includes the spouses and children, the total number of persons dependent on unemployment benefits exceeds one million.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also worth noting for those people who seem to believe that some people wish to rush on to unemployment benefits that the only category of unemployment benefit recipient above the poverty line is that of the unemployed person receiving the married benefit of $163.30. All other categories are below the poverty line. The difference between unemployment benefits and the poverty line is as much as $59.10 per week on the September quarter 1985 figures. We also know that those people who have to exist below the poverty line do so for a long time. Some 57 per cent of the unemployed have been so for more than six months, almost 200,000 of the unemployed have been so for longer than 12 months, and 105,000 have been unemployed for longer than two years.

I do not think that it takes very much imagination to realise what that would do to an individual in our society and to the spouse and dependent children. However, we must recognise that the majority of long term casualties are in the 15 to 24-year-old age bracket. For a dangerously large proportion of our youth the will and confidence to work is being eroded by constant knock-backs and long periods of unemployment. Studies done overseas, where long term unemployment has been more endemic than in Australia, show that a long period of unemployment, even if followed by some employment, leaves a mark, so that those people who have generally been unemployed for more than 12 months, even if they find a job, on average are out of the work force again within a three to six-month period. In other words, it is not just a matter of finding a job for young people; it is a matter of being able to build the confidence in those young people to give them the courage and the view ahead to enable them to keep going and to give them the skills and the approach necessary to retain a job once they find it.

It is a pity that so many people seem to be willing to knock young people who are struggling hard and have enormous difficulty in a society to which they have not yet had a chance to contribute, yet they are being blamed for the ills of that society. When talking about unemployment, we must recognise that it is not just an economic problem, it is a national tragedy. I do not suggest that the Government does not recognise this fact or even that it has failed to respond. There are a plethora of schemes of which the community employment program is but one. However, I point to one problem that needs to be raised. I hope that the Minister, in his reply to the second reading debate, will respond to my concerns about a particular aspect of youth employment in the community employment program. We must be very much aware that it has spawned its own bureaucracy and consequently its own detailed guidelines. Earlier in this debate, Senator Vanstone referred to problems that local government groups have experienced in complying with these detailed CEP guidelines. I am sure that many other senators have received representations from many worthy organisations undertaking unemployment relief schemes which are entirely consistent with the Government's general policy statements yet which have simply withered away because for some reason they do not fit the detailed bureaucratic guidelines which have been established.

I refer to but two which have come to my notice. The first is the bridging the gap scheme, which finds employment for particularly disadvantaged youth by a network of monitors who, most frequently, are employers in a local area. The bridging the gap scheme has found 1,555 permanent jobs on a budget of $62,000. That is $40 on average per job in 1985 figures. On any costing, that figure is extraordinarily low. The second scheme concerns the Waverley Youth Resource Centre, which incorporates the Rotary Youth Bank. This centre is not a job-seeking centre and does not provide work projects. However, it goes to the heart of the matter which I raised earlier. It provides counselling services, which are just as important as the job-seeking exercise because if we are to learn anything from the research of countries which have suffered this problem before, that counselling exercise must be available. The Waverley Youth Resource Centre, which includes the Rotary Youth Bank, provides counselling services dealing with the entire range of problems encountered by the unemployed, including vocational, personal and job-seeking skills. The success rate between 28 May 1984 and 4 November 1985, during which the service had 403 participants, was 80 per cent-an extraordinarily high success rate in anybody's terms. The service was established with the assistance of a $35,000 CEP grant.

Following some comments that have been made in this debate, I add some on the other side. Around Australia there have been some extraordinary success stories in the scheme. Thousands of people, of all ages, have been supported and assisted. I would not like my comments to be taken to be critical of the work that has already been done. My remarks are directed much more to what additional assistance may be provided. The $35,000 grant that I spoke of-the initial funding for the CEP-was augmented by a local council grant of some $70,000. Unfortunately that scheme now falls between all of the current government employment assistance scheme guidelines-that is, the grant which is necessary for its continuation does not seem to be available because the scheme does not come within any existing departmental guidelines.

I think it must be admitted that it is extremely disappointing to find that a worthwhile scheme, which has got up and running with Commonwealth money, is now unable to continue because of the way the guidelines have been put together. This highly successful program will simply now have to close down. The cost to the Government so far has been about $300 for each unemployed person for whom a placement has been found. The $20,000 grant which is necessary would represent about 20 per cent of the total running costs or around $200 per placement.

Due to the shortness of time I have been able to raise only two items. However, I think the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) will get the gist of the point I am trying to make-that is, that having set guidelines for perfectly respectable and useful reasons, I think we are now finding that many worthwhile schemes which previously had been funded by the Commonwealth are being excluded. I think there is a solution to the problem. I would welcome the Minister's response on what I believe is a sensible way to handle this matter-that is, that the Government should be able to set aside a fixed percentage of the total funds devoted to unemployment assistance projects for special one-off projects which have been demonstrably successful. I am quite happy that the projects have to be demonstrably successful before an application can be made for inclusion in the special category that I am suggesting. It seems to me ultimately that any weeding out process ought to weed out the unsuccessful schemes and leave the successful schemes to continue. This is preferable to arbitrarily putting in place guidelines which winnow through, not in terms of success or failure but in terms of some other non-relevant arbitrary guideline. I believe that there should be an obligation to demonstrate the success of schemes for which continuing funding is required. If success is not able to be demonstrated the very much sought after funds ought to be redirected to new schemes to see whether they can succeed. In any event, it seems to me that those which have succeeded and have shown that they are successful should not subsequently be excluded. The Waverley scheme has been very successful in raising 80 per cent of its own operational funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you put new people into that?

—New people are coming into it all the time. In fact, the scheme has a reasonable turnover. The difficulty now is that the scheme just does not seem to fit into any of the current guidelines. However, it has been successful. I believe that a fixed percentage of money set aside to deal with one-off matters would be the way to handle this problem. I think we find that the best schemes are those which ultimately are able to attract some of their own funds and which are not totally dependent upon government finance. I put to the Minister, and hope that he might be able to consider sympathetically, the types of problems which obviously arise in regard to a number of highly successful programs which, I would like to emphasise, were government funded initially and which have been demonstrably successful in carrying out the work to which the people involved have dedicated themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that, like all previous speakers in this debate-in this chamber and in the other chamber-I support the Community Employment Amendment Bill 1986. This piece of legislation will extend the community employment program for a further three years beyond 30 June this year. The community employment program was a major initiative of the Hawke Labor Government following its election in March 1983. When we came into office at that time we found the economy in a parlous state. We found it perhaps in its worst ever recession-certainly the worst in the last 50 years since the Great Depression of the 1930s. That impacted on nobody more than on the ordinary wage and salary earner of this country. At that time, as a result of the disastrous policies of the Fraser Government, we found that the unemployment rate was reaching 10 per cent and continuing to rise. The policies of the previous Government, disastrous though they may have been, had taken effect on the average wage and salary income earner of this country. The Fraser Government had failed, and failed miserably, to fulfil all the promises that it had given to the people of Australia in three previous elections. Of course, the result of the 1983 election, re-endorsed in the 1984 election, was that the Fraser Government-the Liberal-Country Party Government of that time-was tossed into oblivion.

SPEECH.PARA: Faced with the economic problems that we had and an economy that was in recession, with unemployment and inflation rates in double digits, the Hawke Government embarked on a twofold objective. That twofold objective was not to cut inflation at the expense of jobs but to do both in tandem-to drop inflation and to increase the rate of employment. One of the initiatives of the Government was the introduction of the community employment program, or CEP, as it is more commonly known. The program has now been in existence for close on three years and it has, by any standard or any measurement, been very successful. Statistical evidence which we have to hand and which has been produced in the reports put out by the community employment program people is but one indicator of the success of the program. For example, a total of 1,698 projects have been approved in my own State of Western Australia since the introduction of the program. That program has created 9,197 jobs for Western Australia. A total of $100.3m has been spent in my State, and in terms of population that payment has kept pace with the payments that have been made to the other States.
The program has been particularly successful in dealing with people who are termed as long term unemployed. On average, participants have been unemployed for 50 weeks prior to joining the program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you do something about them?
—I did not even know that Senator Lewis was in the chamber. He has been so well behaved in recent days.
—Those poor people have been out of work for 50 weeks. You are going to give them six months.

—Those people who are caught in long term unemployment are rather like the people who sit on the Opposition benches. They are caught in a catch-22 situation. I think we will have to instigate some new special projects under the community employment program for those members on the Opposition benches in this place and in the other place who do not know what they will do following the next election. I really think that Senator Lewis will be one of the greater problems that we will have to face. We will have to have an individual program for him in the next special program.
—Make sure it is Priority One.

—I am not so sure it will be Priority One for him. A couple of his colleagues might get precedence over him. We have done things for the long term unemployed. Those people are, as I said in jest perhaps, caught in a catch-22 situation. The community that we live in judges people not so much on their looks and their abilities, as on what they do. It is common for a person meeting someone in a pub, in a club, on a bus, on a train or wherever people meet each other to ask him what he is, whether he is a fitter and turner, a politician, a teacher or whatever. People identify themselves with the work that they do. The long term unemployed, particularly the youth, reply that they are on unemployment benefits. That in itself draws a stigma. Many of them reject the tag that has been put on them-dole bludgers. Thank heavens use of that expression is dying out somewhat now. These people do go out and chase jobs, but when they front up to an employer the first question that is generally asked is: `What is your experience?' If these people have never worked previously, they are never going to have any experience, so they are caught in a catch-22 situation. They cannot get a job because they have got no experience and because they have not got a job they are not going to get experience. We have done things for them in this program. The analysis of the program's effect has proved that the assessments are having some value in this area. A survey was carried out in March last year into whether or not the program had been effective in training people to play a role in the work force. That survey showed that 41 per cent of those who had participated in the CEP were in employment six months after leaving the project. A total of 59 per cent had been employed at some time during the six-month period.
—What about the poor kids who were not in employment? Imagine how they feel-the 60 per cent who were not in employment.

—I think I would probably know better that the honourable senator does how they feel, because at least I and people on this side of the House meet with them, talk with them and have an understanding and an affinity with them. The coalition parties condemned these people to oblivion, never to play a productive role in society. Those opposite who have spoken in this debate should be ashamed that, when in government, they did not institute programs such as this and sought, through economic policies, to make a sacrifice of the youth, the future generation of Australians, in order to satisfy their short term political ambitions-ambitions which have been rejected on two occasions since 1983 by the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lewis interjected and said: `What about the other 60 per cent?'. If he had kept quiet, had not interjected and had listened for a while, or even read the reports of the program or the results of the survey, he would have found that I was not talking about 60 per cent. I went on to say that a commissioned survey showed that some 59 per cent of the people who had taken part in the CEP had work at some time or other in the following six months. They were out there working, albeit for a short period through this band-aid project, earning money and gaining confidence which will stand them in good stead for the future when they seek to join the labour force on a full time basis. Other research by the Bureau of Labour Market Research shows that the participants in this type of program gained a continuous improvement in their psychological well-being. This is an indicator that the program has been working.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Wednesday I put the case for an extension to seven years of the time in which people ought to be able to take action over damages caused by defective products. One of the examples I gave was the Dalkon shield episode where, despite the efforts of the A. H. Robins company to conceal exactly what it knew and when, there was enough evidence on the public record to show that moral principles had been consistently trampled in the search for quick corporate profits. Nearly 150,000 Dalkon shields were distributed in Australia out of a total of 4 1/2 million sold in 80 countries. We were apparently the third best market. Now some 3,000 Australian women have been joined in United States of America litigation after the A. H. Robins company's successful petition in its home town of Richmond, Virginia, to take advantage of the United States bankruptcy laws and put an end to the mounting numbers of claims for personal injury due to the Dalkon shield.

SPEECH.PARA: More and more cases were being brought successfully as a result of the information available on the public record. Many of these were settled out of court, especially if a threat of production of documents was pending. For instance, in 1984, 198 women jointly received a record settlement of $38m. Among these were 11 whose children had major birth defects, including hydrocephalus, and two whose children were stillborn. In that same year, 1984, Judge Miles W. Lord of the Minnesota jurisdiction assigned two special masters to go to Richmond, the headquarters of A. H. Robins, to expedite pre-trial discovery. Quite a few obstacles were put in their way, but they were able to get at material previously withheld from the courts. The report of the special masters, Peter Thompson and Thomas Bartsh, a year later began:

We conclude that Plaintiffs have established a strong prima facie case that A. H. Robins Co. Inc., has, with the knowledge and participation of in-house counsel, engaged in an ongoing fraud by knowingly misrepresenting the nature, quality, safety and efficacy of the Dalkon Shield. The ongoing fraud has also involved the destruction or withholding of relevant evidence.

From 15,000 pages of documents which were produced for inspection by the special masters various conclusions can be drawn. Among the conclusions drawn were: That the developer of the Dalkon shield was no longer either a credible witness or a credible scientist; that Robins officials knew that the results of four studies given extensive publicity at the end of 1972 were inaccurate and misleading; that a memo on the use of copper in the Dalkon shield corroborated the charge of a former Robins defence lawyer that documents had been pulled from files so that they would not be produced in litigation. As the pressure and the law suits mounted, increasingly the Robins company sought to limit its liabilities. That is why I have risen to speak this afternoon. In April last year it announced the creation of a $615m reserve fund for paying Dalkon shield claims until the year 2002. Naturally that move created taxation advantages for the company.

In July, Robins was unsuccessful in its attempts to get all claims against it that included punitive damages relief consolidated into one class action. Just two months earlier a Wichita jury had awarded a record $7.5m in punitive damages on top of $1.1m in compensatory damages to a woman who had lost her uterus and ovaries after wearing a Dalkon shield for nine years. An outside consultant estimates that some 88,000 of the 2.2 million American women who wore the shield have suffered injury and that claims could be expected from at least 20,000 of them. By June 1985 Robins and its insurers had paid $378.3m to settle 9,230 cases and had incurred legal expenses of $107.3m. Over 5,000 suits were then pending. Claims were coming in from outside the United States.

It was in this atmosphere that Robins filed for pre-emptive bankruptcy on 21 August to protect itself from the continuing burden of litigation. The National Women's Health Network was outraged by the move and unsuccessfully sought to have Chapter 11 petitions thrown out. It also argued that Robins's civic contributions in Richmond, Virginia, created a climate of sympathy that would be detrimental to the claimants' position. If there were to be proceedings, it said, they should be in the American capital.

The whole episode raised a number of fundamental questions for Australia, some of them of quite great difficulty to resolve and some of them of immediate great urgency. There is, at the outset, the very vexed question of the safety of contraceptives and, for that matter, other consumer goods. Balancing the risk of injury with the potential benefits to the community is always going to be tricky. However, no one should be thrown on to the scrap heap as a result of being injured. If we as a society allow the distribution of products with nearly negligible attached risks, we must have a proper safety net for the victims. Over the years it has become more and more clear that that was not the case with the Dalkon shield in the United States or, in fact, anywhere else. In many respects Australia was treated as a backwater, without the need for the elaborate charades that were played out before the Food and Drug Administration and other centres of influence in the United States. If we rely on manufacturers' integrity as the only defence for the public, from time to time we will find that the corporate profit-seeking bulldozer will splatter a large number of innocent people. If we do not have the proper injury reporting mechanisms, the absence or the withholding of relevant information about the true situation can severely compound the problem.

I point out to the Government today that as from 2 o'clock yesterday the situation is that no more claims will be accepted against the Robins company in the United States courts. I believe that the Australian Government should petition the United States Government to extend this time. Very little advertising has been done within Australia on this matter. It is extremely important that the Government should act quickly to ask immediately, through diplomatic channels, that Australian women be given the chance to continue to put their claims against this company.

Those working in the area tell me there have not been the fundamental changes in reporting procedure that would engender confidence in our danger-detection systems. If we have a major obstacle in the path of victims getting redress, we load the system in favour of the shonks and the fly-by-night operators. It is a disgrace that Australian women are having to apply for justice in the United States rather than having a right to apply for justice here. Admittedly, now we have some coverage under the Trade Practices Act but we do not have the class action mechanism to facilitate proper redress in these tragic large scale cases. However, I am hoping to change that. I hope that at least the Government will support my Bill in this area.

It is unfortunate that we have to make this appeal. I ask the Minister whether he could give me some type of undertaking to take this up with the required powers, both in the Department of Foreign Affairs and in the Department of Health, to make certain that Australian women who have been injured by this device can continue to seek redress in law in the United States.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 20 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are women in Sweden encouraged to undergo a mammogram examination on a regular basis, usually in conjunction with Pap smear tests?

(2) Have the costs of individual examinations in Sweden been reduced from $60 to $20 and the mortality rate from breast cancer in Sweden been reduced by some 31 per cent, as a result of such widespread encouragement?

(3) Will the Minister for Health instruct the National Health and Medical Research Council to undertake a feasibility study into the introduction of a universal mammogram screening program in Australia, with estimates of costs of such examinations being undertaken in Australia varying from $2,500 to $20,000 per 1000 women screened; if not, why not?

(4) At what cost to the community would the Minister consider such a scheme to be financially viable, given that the unit cost per examination could be significantly reduced by the introduction of a universal scheme and by encouraging women to have such an examination when a Pap smear examination is carried out, and considering the Government's budgetary considerations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Medical authorities in most western countries, including Sweden, encourage women of certain ages to undergo mammographic examination at regular intervals.
It is often feasible to make the arrangements for mammographic examination (which requires sophisticated radiological equipment) at the time of performance of a Pap smear test.

(2) A report of a Swedish trial investigating the efficacy of mammography in reducing mortality from breast cancer appeared in ``The Lancet'' medical journal on 13 April 1985. This trial, involving two counties of Sweden and women aged 40 years and over, reported a reduction of 31 per cent in mortality from breast cancer in the group who were regularly screened compared with a control group after a seven (7) year period. The trial is still not completed.
The 31 per cent reduction in mortality does not apply to Sweden as a whole, nor has a universal mammographic screening program been introduced.
The current cost of mammographic screening on a large scale in Sweden (as on the trial) is SEK 120 per examination (at current exchange rate, approximately $24 Australian).

The large scale Swedish trial uses a single oblique view which is a less expensive option than is performed in Australia. However, a National Health and Medical Research Council Working Party on Screening for Breast Cancer recommended against this technique in Australian practice.
(3) The National Health and Medical Research Council at its 97th Session in June 1984 received and approved a report of a Working Party on Screening for Breast Cancer.
The Working Party made no recommendation on universal mammographic screening, although the Terms of Reference included the issue of screening the whole population, as defined.

The Working Party recommended that the female population over the age of 40 years should be advised that periodic examination of the breast, both clinical and mammographic, is potentially beneficial towards the earlier diagnosis of breast cancer.

(4) The introduction, in the future, of a universal screening program is a complex issue and all aspects would have to be examined, financial considerations being but one factor. A number of medical trials are still underway (in Canada, and the United Kingdom; the Swedish trial is still not complete). The optimal use of mammography, especially its frequency, is still to be determined. No country has, as yet, decided to introduce universal screening.
It is generally not possible to combine Pap smear and mammographic examinations; one is performed by a general or gynaecological practitioner and the other by a specialised radiological unit.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 March 1986 (Hansard, page 763) Senator Elstob asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning a national study into the situation of mothers who relinquish their children. I undertook to refer the report and the matter to the Minister for Health with the intention of getting an early answer for Senator Elstob in an attempt to see whether we can ensure that conditions improve. The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

ANSWER.PARA: I have seen the study and, as the honourable senator says, it does confirm the absence of professional and family support for relinquishing mothers.

I am aware that research into adoption has tended to ignore the relinquishing mother and I have drawn the report and the honourable senator's concern to the notice of the National Health and Medical Research Council to see what is possible to redress that imbalance.
